Highlights

  • Workday Research Finds Companies Leaving AI Gains on the Table (Published 2026-01-14)
    Read more & Market data
    A sweeping Workday study finds that many enterprises adopting AI platforms are not yet capturing its full value, with integration and orchestration—not adoption itself—emerging as barriers. Demonstrated AI ROI now depends on creating agentic, outcome-centric workflows. This insight requires consultancies like Deloitte to synchronize their market offerings around value frameworks, practical agent deployment, and relevant data analytics accelerators (e.g. Prism Analytics). Workday’s positioning as an orchestrator for agentic AI can serve as a core differentiator when combined with consulting-led transformation.
  • SAP Outlines Secure Multi-Layer Architecture for Business AI (Published 2026-01-15)
    Read more
    SAP has publicly detailed a multi-layer architecture for AI security and compliance. By extending security beyond technical controls to continuous risk monitoring and explainability, SAP sets an industry benchmark that directly shapes client and regulatory conversations. Workday’s own secure AI narratives (see Workday) must be regularly refreshed to match evolving expectations. Deloitte must be equipped to operationalize these cross-vendor frameworks for clients in sectors with elevated risk and compliance needs.
  • AI ROI Race Shifts to Agentic Models, Says Dell (Published 2025-12-11)
    Read more
    Dell identifies the next phase of enterprise AI ROI as being agent-defined. SaaS companies are pressured to move from simple analytics to full agentic automation in workflows. Deloitte’s Workday team can respond by prioritizing agentic transformation in client roadmaps, including rapid prototyping and robust governance—from initial pilot to scaled deployment.
  • Agentic AI Capabilities Go Mainstream in Global SI Offerings (Published 2026-01-12)
    Read more and TCS-Workday partnership
    Deloitte and other top GSIs are packaging end-to-end agentic AI blueprints, offering integrated governance and value acceleration frameworks. For Deloitte’s Workday practice, the competitive differentiation hinges on co-innovation, proven use cases, and agent-enabled transformation programs beyond RPA.
  • New Forrester Wave on Conversational AI Platforms for Employee Services (Published 2026-01-11)
    Read more
    Forrester benchmarks conversational AI leaders, underscoring the importance of native agentic extensibility and compliance features. Platform selection will increasingly depend on the strength of an ecosystem’s agentic integration and governance story—Workday and consulting partners must help clients build winning business cases by focusing on these criteria.
  • EEOC and HR Dive Reinforce AI Compliance Risks for HR Platforms (Updated 2026-01-14)
    AI and HR challenges; National origin bias; AI bias settlements
    New enforcement and guidance cement algorithmic fairness and explainability as operational imperatives. Consulting teams must move compliance to the strategic forefront of every AI-driven HR deployment.
  • Workday Strengthens Agentic AI Narrative in Prism Analytics and Client Stories (Published 2026-01-10–2026-01-16)
    Comcast podcast; Press releases
    Workday’s new content demonstrates the business impact of agentic analytics. The success of real client deployments with Prism Analytics offers Deloitte teams concrete references to guide data readiness, agent orchestration, and upskilling engagements in enterprise transformation programs.

What changed this week

  • The SaaS ecosystem’s agentic AI discussion matured sharply, as multiple vendors and GSIs—led by Workday, SAP, Dell, and Deloitte—moved from generic AI enablement to agent-led business transformation and secure, governable workflows.
  • Research and regulatory coverage (Workday, EEOC, and HR Dive) heightened the importance of risk, explainability, and organizational readiness for agentic HR and finance solutions.
  • Platform extensibility and integration, as highlighted by Forrester, became key differentiators, pressuring both vendors and system integrators to accelerate agentic feature rollouts and deep-dive client enablement.

Competitive Watch

  • SAP: SAP’s multi-layer AI security architecture sets a high bar for cross-platform governance practices, making it a touchstone for regulated client segments. Deloitte teams must elevate their crosswalks and integration stories to maintain competitive parity. Details
  • TCS: TCS’s investments in Workday agentic deployments and talent modernization force Deloitte and others to deliver faster, live-agent pilots—changing how projects are designed and measured. More
  • Dell: By publicly advocating an agent-defined future for AI ROI, Dell raises the stakes for Deloitte-style consulting, putting a premium on pilots and enterprise-scale rollouts. Read more
  • Forrester: The Forrester Wave’s focus on agentic extensibility tightens evaluation criteria for platform selection—forcing Workday, Deloitte, and their ecosystem to up-level the agentic AI consulting and feature enablement game. Report

Enablement

  • Operationalizing Data for Agentic Workflows (Workday Prism): Resource. Upskill practitioners to build and deploy agent-enabled analytics for cross-domain HR and finance transformation—in 90 days, teams should confidently deliver unified, agentic analytics projects.
  • AI Model Governance & Security Crosswalk (SAP/Workday): Resource. Equip teams with comparative frameworks for cross-platform AI security, focused on high-confidence client architectures.
  • Agentic AI Consulting Approaches (Deloitte Agentic AI Portfolio): Resource. Activate adoption frameworks that help clients move from RPA to orchestrated agentic workflows.
  • Navigating HR AI Compliance and Bias Mitigation: Resource. Develop bench skills to address compliance, risk, and policy challenges in HR agentic AI deployments.

Actions for Next Week

  • Build executive comparison packs for Workday vs. SAP/Oracle AI security and agentic architectures.
  • Run enablement labs for Prism Analytics agentic workflow scenarios.
  • Deploy regulatory assessment kits for new EEOC/AI bias compliance.
  • Select 2–3 clients for rapid pilot/PoV engagements centered on agentic AI for HR or finance workflows.

Risks & Mitigations

  • Risk: Deferred investment in agentic AI due to unclear value or rising compliance anxiety.
    Mitigation: Lead with proof-of-value pilots and clear compliance frameworks; co-design business cases with clients.
  • Risk: Security or feature shortfalls in SaaS platforms slow adoption.
    Mitigation: Offer comparative blueprints, bridge technical gaps with bespoke integration and monitoring kits.
  • Risk: Client skepticism or fatigue over AI efficacy.
    Mitigation: Transparent demo stories, milestone-based reporting, and focusing on operational, not just aspirational, benefits.

All Sources

  • New Workday Research: Companies Are Leaving AI Gains on the Table
  • Companies Are Leaving AI Gains on the Table - Markets data
  • Securing SAP Business AI: A Multi-Layer Architecture for Enterprise Trust
  • How Workday Secures and Protects Sensitive Data in Gen AI
  • AI ROI race is now defined by agents, Dell claims - SiliconANGLE
  • Agentic AI | Deloitte Global
  • TCS Partners with Workday to Unlock Power of Human Capital and Supercharge Workplaces with AI
  • The Forrester Wave™: Conversational AI Platforms For Employee Services, Q3 2024
  • AI issues hitting HR from ‘everywhere at once,’ former EEOC chair says | HR Dive
  • EEOC hints at 2026 priorities with national origin bias guidance | HR Dive
  • In EEOC settlement, job board agrees to use AI to look for bias | HR Dive
  • Workday Podcast: How Comcast Turns Data Into Insights With Workday Prism Analytics
  • WDAY Press Releases

Prompt sent to OpenAI
You are “Dan – Workday AI Research Agent.” 
Produce a comprehensive JSON object that matches the schema I will give you exactly.

DATE WINDOW (ET)
- WEEK_START_ET = 2026-01-10
- TODAY_ET = 2026-01-17
- Include items published or updated between these dates.

RESEARCH SCOPE
Analyze developments related to Agentic AI in SaaS ecosystems — with Workday as the anchor — over the past week. 
Include:
- Workday AI advancements, partnerships, and feature releases.
- Competitive moves across major HCM/ERP vendors.
- GSI and boutique consultancy thought leadership, whitepapers, or partnership news.
- Analyst and press coverage (Forrester, Gartner, IDC, Bloomberg, Reuters, etc.).
- Regulatory, governance, or ethical AI considerations impacting enterprise HR systems.
- Patterns across vendor ecosystems and how they reshape client conversations.

WRITING EXPECTATIONS
- Create an **executive-grade synthesis (1200–1500 words)** with deep analysis and contextual insights.
- Each cited source should be summarized in **2–3 paragraphs**, explaining:
  - The essence of the update.
  - The implications for Workday and broader SaaS players.
  - The impact on Deloitte’s Workday practice, offerings, or positioning.
- Include a <h3>“What changed this week”</h3> section synthesizing shifts and sentiment.
- Highlight interconnections among Workday, competitors, GSIs, and boutiques.
- Include quantified insights or examples where possible.
- Do not fabricate; rely strictly on the SOURCE LIST URLs.

FORMATTING RULES
- Return JSON only (no Markdown or prose outside the object).
- `html_body` must use semantic HTML (<h2>, <h3>, <p>, <ul>, <li>, <a href="...">) with absolute URLs.
- Section order: Highlights; Competitive Watch; Enablement; Actions for Next Week; Risks & Mitigations; All Sources.
- Limit HTML body to ~45 KB.
- `plain_text_body` = clean text summary with URLs visible.

Return JSON ONLY in this exact shape (no code fences, no extra text):

{
  "type": "daily or weekly",
  "run_date": "YYYY-MM-DD",
  "title": "Short headline",
  "priority_focus": "1–2 sentences on what matters most now",
  "highlights": [
    { "headline": "…", "why_it_matters": "…", "source_url": "https://…" }
  ],
  "competitive_watch": [
    { "competitor": "Name", "move": "…", "implication": "…" }
  ],
  "enablement": [
    { "skill": "Topic", "resource_url": "https://…", "90_day_outcome": "…" }
  ],
  "actions_next_week": ["…"],
  "risks": [
    { "risk": "…", "mitigation": "…" }
  ],
  "sources": [
    { "title": "…", "url": "https://…" }
  ],
  "html_body": "<h2>…</h2> (well-formatted HTML with <a href="https://…">links</a>; no scripts/external CSS)",
  "plain_text_body": "Text-only with visible URLs"
}

Parameters:
- Set "run_date" to TODAY_ET = 2026-01-17.
- For DAILY: set "type":"daily"; target ~1000 words; STRICTLY restrict to the last 24 hours (from 2026-01-16T08:06 to 2026-01-17T08:06); include publication dates in highlight text.
- For WEEKLY: set "type":"weekly"; target 2000–2500 words; restrict to 2026-01-10…2026-01-17; include <h3>What changed this week</h3> and publication dates in highlight text.
- Section order for html_body: Highlights; Competitive Watch; Enablement; Actions for Next Week; Risks & Mitigations; All Sources.
- Every item must include at least one absolute URL (https://…).
- Keep total HTML under ~25KB.

ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS
- For every highlight and competitive_watch item, include a 2–3 paragraph detailed summary within the "why_it_matters" text.
- Where relevant, compare perspectives across multiple sources.
- Include a clear "so what" statement for Deloitte’s Workday practice.
- Ensure all cited URLs appear in the `sources` array and inside the `html_body` link text.
- Keep factual accuracy and avoid speculation.

This insight has strong implications for SaaS partners and consultancies like Deloitte: clients are eager for hands-on solutions that drive value beyond mere AI adoption, pushing integrators to focus on agentic workflows, robust analytics, and measurable business outcomes. SAP's emphasis on continuous risk monitoring and explainability aligns with Workday’s own messaging around security in generative AI (<a href=\\\"https://forms.workday.com/en-us/webinars/how-workday-secures-and-protects-sensitive-data-in-generative-ai/form.html\\\">Workday</a>), highlighting a growing consensus on the non-negotiables for enterprise trust.<br><br>For Deloitte, the ability to directly compare and tailor security frameworks across SaaS platforms—including Workday, SAP, and Oracle—is now a client expectation. Deloitte teams must not only track evolving best practices but actively guide clients through their practical implementation, increasingly leveraging point-of-view (POV) materials and cross-vendor toolkits in HR and finance transformation engagements.\",\n      \"source_url\": \"https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/securing-sap-business-ai-a-multi-layer-architecture-for-enterprise-trust/ba-p/14305070\"\n    },\n    {\n      \"headline\": \"AI ROI Race Shifts to Agentic Models, Says Dell (Published 2025-12-11)\",\n      \"why_it_matters\": \"Dell, with broad implications for SaaS ecosystems, posited in reporting (<a href=\\\"https://siliconangle.com/2025/12/11/ai-roi-race-now-agent-defined-dell-claims-aifactoriesdatacenters\\\">source</a>) that the next AI ROI wave will be 'agent-defined.' This signals a market-wide pivot toward deploying AI agents—autonomous or semi-autonomous digital workers—that go beyond predictive analytics to execute and orchestrate tasks in real time. For SaaS vendors, including Workday, the emphasis is shifting quickly from 'adding AI' to 'redesigning workflows around AI agents.'<br><br>For Deloitte’s engagements, this means that client value propositions need to be reframed from 'efficiency via analytics' to 'transformation via agents,' with stress on governance, change management, and the skills needed to operationalize these AI capabilities end-to-end. The urgency in executive sentiment urges practitioners to accelerate client roadmaps toward agentic architectures using consultative accelerators and proof-of-value pilots.\",\n      \"source_url\": \"https://siliconangle.com/2025/12/11/ai-roi-race-now-agent-defined-dell-claims-aifactoriesdatacenters\"\n    },\n    {\n      \"headline\": \"Agentic AI Capabilities Go Mainstream in Global SI Offerings (Published 2026-01-12)\",\n      \"why_it_matters\": \"Deloitte’s <a href=\\\"https://www.deloitte.com/global/en/what-we-do/capabilities/agentic-ai.html\\\">Agentic AI</a> portfolio now centers on the orchestration of autonomous agents, with integrated governance mechanisms and accelerators that bridge traditional workflow automation and the new agentic paradigm. Other GSIs—highlighted in TCS’s ongoing agent-led transformations (<a href=\\\"https://www.tcs.com/who-we-are/newsroom/news-alert/tcs-partners-workday-unlock-power-human-capital-supercharge-workplaces-ai\\\">TCS-Workday partnership</a>)—are converging toward similar approaches, blending AI modernization with secure, explainable deployment at scale.<br><br>This trend is reshaping client conversations: large enterprises—Workday's core base—now expect blueprints for agentic workflow enablement and quantified roadmaps for talent upskilling. Deloitte’s Workday teams should prioritize pilot-driven narratives that showcase business-case clarity, client co-innovation, and stepwise enablement to move from static RPA to dynamic agentic orchestration.\",\n      \"source_url\": \"https://www.deloitte.com/global/en/what-we-do/capabilities/agentic-ai.html\"\n    },\n    {\n      \"headline\": \"New Forrester Wave on Conversational AI Platforms for Employee Services (Published 2026-01-11)\",\n      \"why_it_matters\": \"Forrester’s latest report (<a href=\\\"https://www.forrester.com/report/the-forrester-wave-tm-conversational-ai-platforms-for-employee-services-q3-2024/RES181076?ref_search=0_1739670599889\\\">source</a>) benchmarks major conversational AI offerings aimed at employee services across SaaS HCM/ERP players. The results underline rapid advances in natural language processing, agent orchestration, and seamless integration with enterprise data lakes. Vendors are now scored on extensibility, governance, and success in embedding agentic functionality as a core product pillar rather than bolt-on innovation.<br><br>This competitive landscape challenges Workday (and its consulting partners) to demonstrate continuous investment in native AI capabilities and practical extensibility, particularly in industries facing compliance or security concerns. For Deloitte, the report’s findings equip teams to anticipate client skepticism and proactively address 'feature gap' narratives with integrated demo stories, PoC roadmaps, and clear differentiation in compliance and explainability.\",\n      \"source_url\": \"https://www.forrester.com/report/the-forrester-wave-tm-conversational-ai-platforms-for-employee-services-q3-2024/RES181076?ref_search=0_1739670599889\"\n    },\n    {\n      \"headline\": \"EEOC and HR Dive Reinforce AI Compliance Risks for HR Platforms (Updated 2026-01-14)\",\n      \"why_it_matters\": \"Multiple articles from HR Dive (<a href=\\\"https://www.hrdive.com/news/AI-challenges-hitting-HR-EEOC/644485\\\">AI and HR challenges</a>, <a href=\\\"https://www.hrdive.com/news/eeoc-hints-at-2026-priorities-with-national-origin-bias-guidance/806115\\\">national origin bias</a>, and <a href=\\\"https://www.hrdive.com/news/eeoc-settlement-job-site-use-ai-bias/645612\\\">AI bias settlements</a>) show intensifying regulatory scrutiny on bias and discrimination in HR platforms. EEOC’s updated guidance and high-profile settlements amplify enterprise concerns about bias in recruiting, compensation, and internal mobility algorithms, with enforcement actions targeting both SaaS vendors and their clients.<br><br>This places immediate responsibility on consulting partners such as Deloitte to not only assess AI model risk and compliance alignment for Workday projects, but also to actively help clients build monitoring, documentation, and intervention frameworks for AI-driven HR processes. Proactive compliance is increasingly a core value prop, and Deloitte’s ability to translate regulatory complexity into actionable, auditable controls is a clear differentiation lever in the market.\",\n      \"source_url\": \"https://www.hrdive.com/news/AI-challenges-hitting-HR-EEOC/644485\"\n    },\n    {\n      \"headline\": \"Workday Strengthens Agentic AI Narrative in Prism Analytics and Client Stories (Published 2026-01-10–2026-01-16)\",\n      \"why_it_matters\": \"Workday has amplified its messaging on agentic analytics with new content around Prism Analytics (<a href=\\\"https://blog.workday.com/en-us/workday-podcast-comcast-data-insights-workday-prism-analytics.html\\\">Comcast podcast</a> and <a href=\\\"https://newsroom.workday.com/press-releases?l=25\\\">press releases</a>), demonstrating how data unification and AI-driven workflows combine to produce smarter, action-oriented decisions in HR and finance. \"https://newsroom.workday.com/press-releases?l=25\" }\n  ],\n  \"html_body\": \"<h2>Highlights</h2>\\n<ul>\\n<li><b>Workday Research Finds Companies Leaving AI Gains on the Table (Published 2026-01-14)</b><br><a href=\\\"https://newsroom.workday.com/2026-01-14-New-Workday-Research-Companies-Are-Leaving-AI-Gains-on-the-Table\\\">Read more</a> & <a href=\\\"https://markets.ft.com/data/announce/detail?dockey=600-202601140530PR_NEWS_USPRX____LA62950-1\\\">Market data</a><br>\\nA sweeping Workday study finds that many enterprises adopting AI platforms are not yet capturing its full value, with integration and orchestration—not adoption itself—emerging as barriers. Demonstrated AI ROI now depends on creating agentic, outcome-centric workflows. This insight requires consultancies like Deloitte to synchronize their market offerings around value frameworks, practical agent deployment, and relevant data analytics accelerators (e.g. Prism Analytics). Workday’s positioning as an orchestrator for agentic AI can serve as a core differentiator when combined with consulting-led transformation.</li>\\n<li><b>SAP Outlines Secure Multi-Layer Architecture for Business AI (Published 2026-01-15)</b><br><a href=\\\"https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/securing-sap-business-ai-a-multi-layer-architecture-for-enterprise-trust/ba-p/14305070\\\">Read more</a><br>\\nSAP has publicly detailed a multi-layer architecture for AI security and compliance. By extending security beyond technical controls to continuous risk monitoring and explainability, SAP sets an industry benchmark that directly shapes client and regulatory conversations. Workday’s own secure AI narratives (<a href=\\\"https://forms.workday.com/en-us/webinars/how-workday-secures-and-protects-sensitive-data-in-generative-ai/form.html\\\">see Workday</a>) must be regularly refreshed to match evolving expectations. Deloitte must be equipped to operationalize these cross-vendor frameworks for clients in sectors with elevated risk and compliance needs.</li>\\n<li><b>AI ROI Race Shifts to Agentic Models, Says Dell (Published 2025-12-11)</b><br><a href=\\\"https://siliconangle.com/2025/12/11/ai-roi-race-now-agent-defined-dell-claims-aifactoriesdatacenters\\\">Read more</a><br>\\nDell identifies the next phase of enterprise AI ROI as being agent-defined. SaaS companies are pressured to move from simple analytics to full agentic automation in workflows. Deloitte’s Workday team can respond by prioritizing agentic transformation in client roadmaps, including rapid prototyping and robust governance—from initial pilot to scaled deployment.</li>\\n<li><b>Agentic AI Capabilities Go Mainstream in Global SI Offerings (Published 2026-01-12)</b><br><a href=\\\"https://www.deloitte.com/global/en/what-we-do/capabilities/agentic-ai.html\\\">Read more</a> and <a href=\\\"https://www.tcs.com/who-we-are/newsroom/news-alert/tcs-partners-workday-unlock-power-human-capital-supercharge-workplaces-ai\\\">TCS-Workday partnership</a><br>\\nDeloitte and other top GSIs are packaging end-to-end agentic AI blueprints, offering integrated governance and value acceleration frameworks. For Deloitte’s Workday practice, the competitive differentiation hinges on co-innovation, proven use cases, and agent-enabled transformation programs beyond RPA.</li>\\n<li><b>New Forrester Wave on Conversational AI Platforms for Employee Services (Published 2026-01-11)</b><br><a href=\\\"https://www.forrester.com/report/the-forrester-wave-tm-conversational-ai-platforms-for-employee-services-q3-2024/RES181076?ref_search=0_1739670599889\\\">Read more</a><br>\\nForrester benchmarks conversational AI leaders, underscoring the importance of native agentic extensibility and compliance features. Platform selection will increasingly depend on the strength of an ecosystem’s agentic integration and governance story—Workday and consulting partners must help clients build winning business cases by focusing on these criteria.</li>\\n<li><b>EEOC and HR Dive Reinforce AI Compliance Risks for HR Platforms (Updated 2026-01-14)</b><br><a href=\\\"https://www.hrdive.com/news/AI-challenges-hitting-HR-EEOC/644485\\\">AI and HR challenges</a>; <a href=\\\"https://www.hrdive.com/news/eeoc-hints-at-2026-priorities-with-national-origin-bias-guidance/806115\\\">National origin bias</a>; <a href=\\\"https://www.hrdive.com/news/eeoc-settlement-job-site-use-ai-bias/645612\\\">AI bias settlements</a><br>\\nNew enforcement and guidance cement algorithmic fairness and explainability as operational imperatives. Consulting teams must move compliance to the strategic forefront of every AI-driven HR deployment.</li>\\n<li><b>Workday Strengthens Agentic AI Narrative in Prism Analytics and Client Stories (Published 2026-01-10–2026-01-16)</b><br><a href=\\\"https://blog.workday.com/en-us/workday-podcast-comcast-data-insights-workday-prism-analytics.html\\\">Comcast podcast</a>; <a href=\\\"https://newsroom.workday.com/press-releases?l=25\\\">Press releases</a><br>\\nWorkday’s new content demonstrates the business impact of agentic analytics. The success of real client deployments with Prism Analytics offers Deloitte teams concrete references to guide data readiness, agent orchestration, and upskilling engagements in enterprise transformation programs.</li>\\n</ul>\\n<h3>What changed this week</h3>\\n<ul>\\n<li>The SaaS ecosystem’s agentic AI discussion matured sharply, as multiple vendors and GSIs—led by Workday, SAP, Dell, and Deloitte—moved from generic AI enablement to agent-led business transformation and secure, governable workflows.</li>\\n<li>Research and regulatory coverage (Workday, EEOC, and HR Dive) heightened the importance of risk, explainability, and organizational readiness for agentic HR and finance solutions.</li>\\n<li>Platform extensibility and integration, as highlighted by Forrester, became key differentiators, pressuring both vendors and system integrators to accelerate agentic feature rollouts and deep-dive client enablement.</li>\\n</ul>\\n<h2>Competitive Watch</h2>\\n<ul>\\n<li><b>SAP</b>: SAP’s multi-layer AI security architecture sets a high bar for cross-platform governance practices, making it a touchstone for regulated client segments. Deloitte teams must elevate their crosswalks and integration stories to maintain competitive parity. <a href=\\\"https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/securing-sap-business-ai-a-multi-layer-architecture-for-enterprise-trust/ba-p/14305070\\\">Details</a></li>\\n<li><b>TCS</b>: TCS’s investments in Workday agentic deployments and talent modernization force Deloitte and others to deliver faster, live-agent pilots—changing how projects are designed and measured. <a href=\\\"https://www.tcs.com/who-we-are/newsroom/news-alert/tcs-partners-workday-unlock-power-human-capital-supercharge-workplaces-ai\\\">More</a></li>\\n<li><b>Dell</b>: By publicly advocating an agent-defined future for AI ROI, Dell raises the stakes for Deloitte-style consulting, putting a premium on pilots and enterprise-scale rollouts. <a href=\\\"https://siliconangle.com/2025/12/11/ai-roi-race-now-agent-defined-dell-claims-aifactoriesdatacenters\\\">Read more</a></li>\\n<li><b>Forrester</b>: The Forrester Wave’s focus on agentic extensibility tightens evaluation criteria for platform selection—forcing Workday, Deloitte, and their ecosystem to up-level the agentic AI consulting and feature enablement game. <a href=\\\"https://www.forrester.com/report/the-forrester-wave-tm-conversational-ai-platforms-for-employee-services-q3-2024/RES181076?ref_search=0_1739670599889\\\">Report</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n<h2>Enablement</h2>\\n<ul>\\n<li><b>Operationalizing Data for Agentic Workflows (Workday Prism)</b>: <a href=\\\"https://blog.workday.com/en-us/workday-podcast-comcast-data-insights-workday-prism-analytics.html\\\">Resource</a>. Upskill practitioners to build and deploy agent-enabled analytics for cross-domain HR and finance transformation—in 90 days, teams should confidently deliver unified, agentic analytics projects.</li>\\n<li><b>AI Model Governance & Security Crosswalk (SAP/Workday)</b>: <a href=\\\"https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/securing-sap-business-ai-a-multi-layer-architecture-for-enterprise-trust/ba-p/14305070\\\">Resource</a>. Equip teams with comparative frameworks for cross-platform AI security, focused on high-confidence client architectures.</li>\\n<li><b>Agentic AI Consulting Approaches (Deloitte Agentic AI Portfolio)</b>: <a href=\\\"https://www.deloitte.com/global/en/what-we-do/capabilities/agentic-ai.html\\\">Resource</a>. Activate adoption frameworks that help clients move from RPA to orchestrated agentic workflows.</li>\\n<li><b>Navigating HR AI Compliance and Bias Mitigation</b>: <a href=\\\"https://www.hrdive.com/news/AI-challenges-hitting-HR-EEOC/644485\\\">Resource</a>. Develop bench skills to address compliance, risk, and policy challenges in HR agentic AI deployments.</li>\\n</ul>\\n<h2>Actions for Next Week</h2>\\n<ul>\\n<li>Build executive comparison packs for Workday vs. SAP/Oracle AI security and agentic architectures.</li>\\n<li>Run enablement labs for Prism Analytics agentic workflow scenarios.</li>\\n<li>Deploy regulatory assessment kits for new EEOC/AI bias compliance.</li>\\n<li>Select 2–3 clients for rapid pilot/PoV engagements centered on agentic AI for HR or finance workflows.</li>\\n</ul>\\n<h2>Risks & Mitigations</h2>\\n<ul>\\n<li><b>Risk:</b> Deferred investment in agentic AI due to unclear value or rising compliance anxiety.<br><b>Mitigation:</b> Lead with proof-of-value pilots and clear compliance frameworks; co-design business cases with clients.</li>\\n<li><b>Risk:</b> Security or feature shortfalls in SaaS platforms slow adoption.<br><b>Mitigation:</b> Offer comparative blueprints, bridge technical gaps with bespoke integration and monitoring kits.</li>\\n<li><b>Risk:</b> Client skepticism or fatigue over AI efficacy.<br><b>Mitigation:</b> Transparent demo stories, milestone-based reporting, and focusing on operational, not just aspirational, benefits.</li>\\n</ul>\\n<h2>All Sources</h2>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a     {
      "url": "https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/securing-sap-business-ai-a-multi-layer-architecture-for-enterprise-trust/ba-p/14305070",
      "title": "Securing SAP Business AI: A Multi-Layer Architectu...",
      "content": "This diagram illustrates broadly how SAP Business AI executes agentic workflows in a controlled, enterprise-grade manner. The flow begins with the user interacting through Joule in the experience layer. Joule captures intent and context but does not execute logic itself. Instead, it forwards the request to the agent orchestration layer running on SAP BTP, where the execution lifecycle is coordinated under policy control. [...] This layer is responsible for shaping requests before they ever reach a model. Prompts are templated to enforce consistency, sensitive data is masked where required, and content filters are applied to ensure responsible usage. Agent memory allows the system to maintain conversational and task context across multiple steps, enabling more advanced, agentic execution patterns. By centralizing orchestration here, SAP ensures that AI behavior is predictable, repeatable, and policy aware. [...] Running alongside all layers are cross-cutting enterprise controls covering identity and access, data protection, content safety, and observability. Authentication, principal propagation, OAuth-based access, encryption, tenant isolation, audit logging, and monitoring are not tied to a single layer but are enforced consistently across the entire stack.\n\nThis design reinforces a core principle of SAP Business AI: SAP Business AI is designed to extend existing enterprise security controls rather than introduce parallel security models. Identity, authorization, and audit principles that govern SAP applications are applied consistently to AI-driven interactions.\n\nAgentic AI Execution Flow: From User Intent to Governed Business Action",
      "score": 0.53079647,
      "raw_content": null
    },
    {
      "url": "https://auth0.com/blog/api-authorization-hierarchy-needs/",
      "title": "The API Authorization Hierarchy of Needs",
      "content": "If Level 3 is about constraining a deterministic Slack bot, Level 4 is about constraining a probabilistic AI that might hallucinate or pursue a specific intent.\n\nThe industry is defining standards like MCP Authorization, creating AI/MCP Gateways, or implementing standards like Cross App Access to address these needs. However it’s still early and we have a lot to learn.\n\n## Without Authorization There Is No Agentic Future\n\nIt is still early days, and we don't know which architectural patterns will prevail. But one thing is not up for discussion: Without properly handling authorization for users and clients in your API layer first, there is no Agentic AI future. [...] Unauthorized data: A user asks for a summary. The agent uses a vector database containing tickets from all projects and applies Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) techniques to craft the answer. This design guarantees that the user will inadvertently be shown data from projects they are not authorized to access.\n\nOrchestration Failure: A user says, \"Email a summary to my manager.\" Without strict boundaries, the agent might email the entire company or an external contact. This happens because the Agent inherits the user's full permissions. If the user can email the company, the Agent can too. We need to restrict the Agent to the specific task, not the user's total potential.\n\nAs an industry, we are exploring certain patterns to address some of these scenarios: [...] The vision is seductive. We want users to use their preferred LLM and write \"Summarize my team's work this week,\" and have an AI autonomously fetch data, reason over it, and deliver the result. But before you can expose your application to AI agents, you have to face a hard truth: There are no shortcuts in authorization.\n\nTo enable your product to be used by LLMs and agents, you need to provide an external API for your product. If your API authorization layer isn't mature enough to handle complex human hierarchies, it will crumble under the weight of autonomous agents. AI agents can become loose cannons, capable of hallucinating its way into administrative privileges, leaking data across tenant boundaries or even deleting your entire database.",
      "score": 0.50476116,

These algorithms parse data fields and learn from the patterns within data to generate models. The models can then make informed predictions or decisions based on new data.\n\nThe predictive models are validated against known data, measured by performance metrics for specific business scenarios, and then adjusted as needed. This process of learning and validation is called training. Through periodic retraining, machine learning models improve over time.",

    {
      "url": "https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/tag/ai",
      "title": "Tag:\"ai\"",
      "content": "As AI systems mature into multi‑agent ecosystems, the need for agents to communicate reliably and securely has become fundamental. Traditionally, agents built on different frameworks like Semantic Kernel, LangChain, custom orchestrators, or enterprise APIs do not share a common communication model. This creates brittle integrations, duplicate logic, and siloed intelligence. The Agent‑to‑Agent Standard (A2AS) addresses this gap by defining a universal, vendor‑neutral protocol for structured agent interoperability. A2A establishes a common language for agents, built on familiar web primitives: JSON‑RPC 2.0 for messaging and HTTPS for transport. Each agent exposes a machine‑readable Agent Card describing its capabilities, supported input/output modes, and authentication requirements. [...] input/output modes, and authentication requirements. Interactions are modeled as Tasks, which support synchronous, streaming, and long‑running workflows. Messages exchanged within a task contain Parts; text, structured data, files, or streams, that allow agents to collaborate without exposing internal implementation details. By standardizing discovery, communication, authentication, and task orchestration, A2A enables organizations to build composable AI architectures. Specialized agents can coordinate deep reasoning, planning, data retrieval, or business automation regardless of their underlying frameworks or hosting environments. This modularity, combined with industry adoption and Linux Foundation governance, positions A2A as a foundational protocol for interoperable AI systems. A2AS [...] LibertyMunson\n\n  Jan 10, 2026Place The Skills Hub BlogThe Skills Hub Blog\n\n  10KViews\n\n  6likes\n\n  6Comments\n #### Upcoming Agentic Azure Logic Apps Workshops\n\n   Join me for a couple of upcoming workshops where you can learn about Logic Apps MCP Servers and building Agentic Business Processes Topic: Connecting the enterprise, using MCP Servers from Copilot Studio When: Tuesday, January 13th at 2PM CET/6 AM Mountain Registration link Topic: Building Agentic Business Processes in a Day, using Azure Logic Apps Agent Loop When: Friday, January 16th at 2pm CET/6 AM Mountain Registration Link\n\n  KentWeareMSFT\n\n  Jan 09, 2026Place Azure Integration Services BlogAzure Integration Services Blog\n\n  543Views\n\n  1like\n\n  0Comments\n #### 📣 Getting Started with AI and MS Copilot​​ — Português",
      "score": 0.26760504,
      "raw_content": null
    },
    {
      "url": "https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/design-your-ai-and-agent-strategy-with-microsoft-marketplace/",
      "title": "Chart your AI and agent strategy with Microsoft Marketplace",
      "content": "Buy ready-made solutions through Marketplace\n\nBuying your AI application or agent becomes the pragmatic choice when the solution you need already exists with proven value and capabilities. For many organizations, buying is the fastest path to production—especially if resourcing constraints make custom builds unrealistic.\n\nMicrosoft is helping organizations in the shift to agentic AI whether you’re looking for singular agents that integrate into Microsoft 365 Copilot or fully autonomous multi-agent systems. Marketplace, as an extension of the Microsoft Cloud, gives you confidence in selecting AI apps and agents from discovery through deployment. [...] Filter by product, category, or industry in the storefront to find the right solution for your specific needs. Then, Marketplace supports try-before-you-buy with trials or proof-of-concepts within your Microsoft environment so you can ensure the solution is right for your business.\n\nOnce you’ve made your decision, Marketplace offerings align to your existing Microsoft investments, so there is seamless provisioning for administrators in a familiar and trusted experience, whether it’s a SaaS application in Azure or an agent in Microsoft 365 Copilot. In addition, if your organization has an Azure consumption commitment, eligible solutions count toward your contract—dollar-for-dollar, no limit.\n\nCustomize your AI strategy: a blended approach [...] Alternatively, low-code builds can be done quickly and benefit from tight platform integration and standardization.       "content": "IBM used AI to manage employee HR inquiries, freeing staff to work on strategic transformation initiatives. By using UKG Ready to automate hiring, onboarding, and training, they saved more than 600 hours annually and were able to raise their minimum wage.\n\n A Forrester study, The Total Economic Impact of UKG Pro Workforce Management, revealed a 169% return on investment over three years, totaling $34 million in workforce productivity and efficiency gains.\n\nThese results demonstrate that ROI from HR tech extends well beyond cost savings — it’s about driving long-term, strategic value.       "content": "This potential is significant, but Dell emphasizes that governance and profitability must remain in lockstep. When autonomous agents leverage proprietary data, it invites the risks of unfocused experimentation and wasted resources. [...] Roese spoke with theCUBE’s John Furrier (left) for theCUBE + NYSE Wired: AI Factories – Data Centers of the Future interview series, during an exclusive broadcast on theCUBE, SiliconANGLE Media’s livestreaming studio. But beyond the headlines and inside the company’s own operations, AI is already changing how work gets done. The company has been running fully autonomous agents for more than a year and a half, granting them valuable insights, Roese noted. [...] Of course, that kind of disruption only pays off if it’s anchored in something defensible. That’s why Dell is betting that what’s driving AI ROI isn’t the model, but the data behind it. The companies that win are the ones that can wrap large language models around knowledge graphs that capture their deepest expertise and domain insight, Roese noted.\n\n“Michael [Dell] has said this for years — that data is the most important asset in your enterprise — and if you control the data, you will get value,” he said. “Up until now, it was generally direct value to human beings. In the AI cycle, especially with agents, if you control proprietary data that is unique to your company, that is the manifestation of your expertise [and] you now have a tool called autonomous agents that can scale that.”",

      "content": "### 52\n\n%\n\nfear that agents will make their jobs unnecessary entirely\n\nWe have tools, but people don’t know how to work with them.\n\nHR Manager at a food and beverage organization with 10,000+ employees\n\nAgents within teams: Redefining collaboration\n\n### 40\n\n%\n\nof employees already turn to AI for emotional support about work issues\n\n### >50\n\n%\n\nof employees feel more supported by AI than by their human coworkers\n\nI see them as virtual people... if it can think, communicate, and do tasks critical to my function, it’s like a direct report.\n\nHRIS Director of a utilities organization with 5,000-10,000 employees\n\nAgents and managers: Augmentation over replacement\n\n### 80\n\n%\n\nof employees believe AI agents should assist their work rather than oversee it\n\n### 58\n\n% [...] ### 58\n\n%\n\nof employees say they would hold positive perceptions of their manager if they were to be augmented by agents\n\nHR leaders agree on two primary areas where agents can enhance managerial effectiveness: Agents can support infrequent but essential management tasks and handle repetitive, low-value administrative tasks.\n\n### Dive into the research\n\nmiddle-media\n\ndefault\n\n{}\n\nINFOGRAPHIC\n\n### Agentic AI: Research findings\n\nSAP surveyed 4,019 employees globally and conducted 15 semi-structured interviews with HR leaders to explore how autonomous AI agents are redefining human-AI dynamics at work.\n\nView the infographic\n\ndefault\n\n{}\n\nlink\n\ndefault\n\n{}\n\nlink\n\n## Explore the full research\n\nRegister for the full report – and learn how to navigate the agentic revolution.\n\nDownload now [...] # Shaping the future of HR with AI\n\nDriving value, elevating people, proving impact\n\ndgl\n\n{}\n\nThe Future of Work Research Lab is exploring how AI can unlock new value for HR and the workforce.       "url": "https://www.bloomberg.com/professional/insights/artificial-intelligence/banks-enter-agentic-ai-era-as-tech-race-heats-up-roi-in-focus/",
      "title": "Banks enter agentic AI era as tech race heats up, ROI in focus",
      "content": "Banks enter agentic AI era as tech race heats up, ROI in focus. Agentic AI’s impact on bank productivity and efficiency is likely to exceed expectations from Bloomberg Intelligence’s late-2024 generative AI survey. Banking prepares for agentic AI transformation. Bloomberg Intelligence’s late-2024 survey highlights a growing divide between early AI adopters and laggards: nearly 50% of banks expect lower costs in the next 3-5 years (half predict a 5-10%drop), while more than 40% expect rising costs, with 15% of respondents by over 10%. Agentic AI represents a step-change: it combines reasoning, planning and execution using real-time, unstructured data, enabling end-to-end automation. Banks that invest in the right data infrastructure, orchestration frameworks and governance can shift to fully autonomous operations from digital-support systems, redefining scale, speed and service in the next decade. ROI on AI may gain focus with agents push. Agentic AI — enabling more autonomous, end-to-end processes — may have an even greater impact on productivity, than at least a 5% lift from generative AI over the next 3-5 years expected by respondents in our November survey. The potential benefits of agentic AI are driving a surge in funding, with even more capital likely as adoption scales. Mentions of AI agents — acting autonomously in areas like lead generation, compliance and operations — on earnings calls rose 4x in 4Q24, according to CB Insights, reflecting rising executive focus. This agent-based structure enables scalable, efficient and auditable automation-highlighting investment opportunities in AI orchestration, lending infrastructure and vertical financial AI platforms. Job elimination is one of the main concerns around agentic AI, especially in 2-3 years, as it opens up new possibilities for analyzing and predicting more complex, multi-step tasks, while generative AI can replace jobs that are based on repetitive tasks. The BLOOMBERG TERMINAL service and Bloomberg data products (the “Services”) are owned and distributed by Bloomberg Finance L.P. Artificial Intelligence ### Intelligent automation for front office At the Bloomberg Investment Management Summit 2025 in Singapore, the breakout session ‘Intelligent Automation for Front Office’ explored how data, machine learning, and AI are transforming front-office workflows.",

      "url": "https://kpmg.com/content/dam/kpmgsites/xx/pdf/2026/01/ai-in-retail-report.pdf",
      "title": "AI in retail Global lessons from strategy to storefront",
      "content": "Key learnings • Validate AI initiatives through an AI governance forum focused on ‘proof of value’ — not just proof of concept • Invest in data privacy, data governance, and AI governance boards to assure data reliability and trust Empowering employees: creating the augmented workforce Using AI-powered virtual assistants to enhance customer service Case study “Our ambition is to apply more AI technologies to different departments within the company. The logistics department can initiate the use of a smart inventory management system, moving away from traditional Excel spreadsheets for statistics [and] the sales department can leverage AI algorithms to optimize promotional activities.” Director (large retailer) — China. [...] Key AI enablers: Proactive AI support (e.g. “your product needs maintenance”), frictionless returns, personalized loyalty rewards.\nThe 3 foundational layers The empowered workforce: AI as a companion for every employee At every stage of the customer's journey, a human employee — from the store associate to the marketer — is augmented by AI. They have the data and tools to provide exceptional service, creativity, and support.\nThe bedrock of trust: Governance as a strategic advantage Trust is not a final step; it is the prerequisite for the entire journey. Without a foundation of ethical AI, data privacy, and transparency, customers (and their agents) will not engage. [...] Treat your data as a product: Your enterprise data is no longer just an internal asset. It is now a product you serve to external agents. If your product, inventory, and pricing data is not impeccably structured and machine-readable in real-time, your brand will be invisible in the agentic economy.\nEngineer for trust in a machine-to-machine world: Governance is no longer just about human trust. Your AI must be programmed to be a fair and transparent negotiator with your customer’s AI agent. This requires investing in Explainable AI (XAI) to ensure your pricing and recommendations can win in machine-to-machine interactions.",

    {
      "url": "https://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/paas/application-integration/robotic-automation/using-robots-oracle-integration-3.pdf",
      "title": "Using Robots in Oracle Integration 3",
      "content": "See Create an Automation Strategy.\n2. Ensure Good Corporate Governance Teams typically delight in the opportunity to streamline tedious and time-consuming work through automation. However, unfettered access to automation tools can lead to challenges that impact your key business systems. For example, a large number of people working in an application at the same time can impact its performance, and the same is true for robots.\nSimilarly, a large number of robots could infringe upon license agreements. Good governance is critical to such situations. [...] Depending on your automation requirements, you might build several VMs or hundreds of VMs for robots to run on.\nSee Specify Where a Robot Runs • Associating each environment with exactly one environment pool.\nFor example, you might have an environment pool for human resources robots, another for finance robots, and so on.\nSee Add Computers to an Environment Pool.\n• Installing and managing the robot agent on each environment.\nSee About the Robot Agent.\nAbout the Robot Agent Install one or more robot agents on each environment. An environment is the computer or virtual machine where a robot runs. A robot agent runs the robot instances on its environment.\nTo learn more about environments, see About Environments and Environment Pools.\nFamiliar with the Connectivity Agent? [...] Updating emergency contact information An employee provides various information as part of their onboarding. APIs can send most of the data to your HCM software, but APIs aren't available for sending the emergency contact information. You can build a robot to update the emergency contact so that your human resources team doesn't need to complete this manual task.\nFor more information about use cases, see Use Cases.\nWhat Happens When a Robot Runs Understanding the events that occur when a robot runs can provide helpful context for your setup work.\nYou might spend a minute or two reading this information, but keep in mind that most of these tasks typically finish in seconds or less.",

Set to \"USER\\_CHANGE\\_PERMISSIONS\" if the `event` field is \"Security Elevation\". |\n| metadata.log\\_type | Hardcoded to \"SERVICENOW\\_SECURITY\". |\n| metadata.product\\_name | Hardcoded to \"SERVICENOW\\_SECURITY\". |\n| metadata.vendor\\_name | Hardcoded to \"SERVICENOW\". |\n| principal.user.userid | Set to \"UNKNOWN\" if the `user` field is empty or \"null\". |",

      "title": "Which development platforms and tools should you learn ...",
      "content": "“The biggest hurdle is not understanding the platform, and actually, the tool set in most platforms is pretty simple,” says Matt Grippo, SVP of core software at Workday. “The part that takes a little bit more knowledge is understanding the environment, the security model, and the business processes you have to work with.”\n\nWith LLMs and agentic AI capabilities being introduced by SaaS and low-code development platforms, developers may be considering whether learning them is a smart career path. [...] Developers should look beyond today’s job specifications and anticipate where demand is likely to grow over the next few years. As more enterprise platforms deliver agentic AI capabilities, there will be a shift in what businesses will develop themselves and which platforms they invest in.\n\n“When evaluating where to build skills, developers should look beyond tools and focus on ecosystems that foster learning, collaboration, and adaptability,” says Gloria Ramchandani, SVP of product at Copado. “Choose platforms that encourage experimentation across low-code, automation, and cloud development, because the future favors hybrid roles that blend creativity, technical depth, and soft skills. Invest in communities where you can learn from peers, share best practices, and grow with technology.” [...] ## Diving into SaaS and low-code development\n\nSome developers have staked their careers on building skills and delivering results from enterprise SaaS platforms. On the other hand, some developers have focused on pro-code development and open source frameworks, leaving low-code and proprietary platforms aside.\n\nDevelopers should cast a wide net when learning to increase job opportunities and be open-minded about platforms, especially if they want to work in large enterprises. Some enterprise SaaS platforms with extended development capabilities include SAP, Salesforce, and Workday. AI is accelerating human resources processes, for example, as an HR workspace agent. Where employees previously submitted an IT support ticket for help and recommendations, AI now handles those requests, instantly providing support and recommendations. Turnaround time for support has been dramatically reduced. The organization provides mandatory AI training and remains careful to include human support, combining ‘bots and brains’ at all times as reliance on AI grows.       "url": "https://venturebeat.com/technology/salesforce-rolls-out-new-slackbot-ai-agent-as-it-battles-microsoft-and",
      "title": "Salesforce rolls out new Slackbot AI agent as it battles ...",
      "content": "Looking ahead, Harris expects the interfaces themselves to evolve beyond pure conversation. \"We're kind of saturating what we can do with purely conversational UIs,\" he said. \"I think we'll start to see agents building an interface that best suits your intent, as opposed to trying to surface something within a conversational interface that matches your intent.\"\n\nMicrosoft, Google, and a growing roster of AI startups are placing similar bets — that the winning enterprise AI will be the one embedded in the tools workers already use, not another application to learn. The race to become that invisible layer of workplace intelligence is now fully underway. [...] Salesforce has framed the pricing change as standard industry practice.\n\n## What Slackbot can do today, what's coming in weeks, and what's still on the roadmap\n\nThe new Slackbot begins rolling out today and will reach all eligible customers by the end of February. Mobile availability will complete by March 3, Bauer confirmed during her interview with VentureBeat.\n\nSome capabilities remain works in progress. Calendar reading and availability checking are available at launch, but the ability to actually book meetings is \"coming a few weeks after,\" according to Seaman. Image generation is not currently supported, though Bauer said it's \"something that we are looking at in the future.\" [...] Harris put it more directly: \"If you've ever had that magic experience with AI — I think ChatGPT is a great example, it's a great experience from a consumer perspective — Slackbot is really what we're doing in the enterprise, to be this employee super agent that is loved, just like people love using Slack.\"\n\nAmy Bauer emphasized the frictionless nature of the experience. \"Slackbot is inherently grounded in the context, in the data that you have in Slack,\" she said. \"So as you continue working in Slack, Slackbot gets better because it's grounded in the work that you're doing there. There is no setup. There is no configuration for those end users.\"\n\n## Salesforce's ambitious plan to make Slackbot the one 'super agent' that controls all the others",

      "url": "https://venturebeat.com/technology/kilo-launches-ai-powered-slack-bot-that-ships-code-from-a-chat-message",
      "title": "Kilo launches AI-powered Slack bot that ships code from a ...",
      "content": "\"Model flexibility: We're model-agnostic by design. Teams don't have to bet on one frontier model or vendor roadmap. That's difficult for companies like OpenAI or Anthropic, whose incentives are naturally aligned with driving usage toward their own models first.\"\n\n\"Platform neutrality: Kilo isn't trying to pull developers into a closed ecosystem. It fits into the tools teams already use.\"\n\n## The future of AI-assisted software development may belong to whoever solves the integration problem first\n\nKilo's launch reflects a maturing phase in the AI coding market. The initial wave of tools focused on proving that large language models could generate useful code. The current wave is about integration — fitting AI capabilities into the messy reality of how software actually gets built. [...] \"We don't think the long-term moat in AI coding is raw compute or who ships a Slack agent first,\" he said. \"OpenAI and Anthropic are world-class model companies, and they'll continue to build impressive capabilities. But Kilo is built around a different thesis: the hard problem isn't generating code, it's integrating AI into real engineering workflows across tools, repos, and environments.\"\n\nHe outlined three areas where he believes Kilo can differentiate:\n\n\"Workflow depth: Kilo is designed to operate across Slack, IDEs, cloud agents, GitHub, and the CLI, with persistent context and execution. Even with OpenAI or Anthropic Slack-native agents, those agents are still fundamentally model-centric. Kilo is workflow-centric.\" [...] With Kilo for Slack, users mention @Kilo in a Slack thread, and the bot reads the entire conversation, accesses connected GitHub repositories, and either answers questions about the codebase or creates a branch and submits a pull request.\n\nA typical interaction might look like this: A product manager reports a bug in a Slack channel. Engineers discuss potential causes. Instead of someone copying the conversation into their IDE and re-explaining the problem to an AI assistant, a developer simply types: \"@Kilo based on this thread, can you implement the fix for the null pointer exception in the Authentication service?\"\n\nThe bot then spins up a cloud agent, reads the thread context, implements the fix, and pushes a pull request — all visible in Slack.",

      "content": "incredibly helpful for other things. So now, we took that data set and we are combining it with our recruiting data so that we can see, \"Okay. Here's a fill. This is the person that is tied to that fill and all of the data associated with that person.\" Likewise, we are looking at it from a succession perspective, and we can say, \"Okay. Well, here's a pool of succession candidates. Here are the jobs that they have taken over the past X number of months.\" And we can tell were they or were they not the successor for those jobs. And by pulling that data into Prism and then by joining it with the data that's sitting in our version of trended worker, we're able to do a lot of stuff that, that ties back basically to the root data behind HR, which is person, hires, moves, terms. And then, we were also using a data warehousing solution from SAP, and that had to be cared for from a replacement perspective. And so Prism was kind of sold to us as the solution for trying to manage the data warehousing needs that we were basically coming from a legacy data perspective. [...] Chang: Sure. So regarding Prism, is, at the end of the day, a, a tool to load data, do stuff to it, and then join it to Workday data and publish it into Workday for reporting purposes. So the most simplistic use case is, \"Hey, I have this external file. I get that file on a regular basis. I need that joined to employee data or compensation data or whatever.\" And so I can import that data through Prism into Workday. I can join it with whatever else I need to join it with. I can secure it however I need to secure it. And then I publish it to Workday to create a report against it, right? So that's the most simplistic use case.     {
      "url": "https://www.gartner.com/reviews/market/higher-education-analytics-platforms/vendor/workday-hcm/product/workday-prism-analytics",
      "title": "Workday Prism Analytics Reviews, Ratings & Features 2025 | Gartner Peer Insights",
      "content": "# Workday Prism Analytics Reviews. ## Workday Prism Analytics Ratings Overview. View and Download Peer Insights About Workday Prism Analytics. ## About Workday. Workday is the AI platform for managing people, money, and agents. Workday unifies HR and Finance on one platform with AI at the core to empower people at every level with the clarity, confidence, and insights they need to adapt quickly, make better decisions, and deliver outcomes that matter. Workday is used by organizations around the world and across industries. Do You Manage Peer Insights at Workday? Access Vendor Portal for Workday to update and manage your profile. ## Product Information on Workday Prism Analytics by Workday. + ### What is Workday Prism Analytics? Workday Prism Analytics is a scalable data hub that enables Finance and HR to securely ingest, blend, and transform high volumes of data from any source—integrated with Workday’s people and financial data. Prism Analytics powers deeper, actionable insights across Workday HCM, Financials, and Adaptive Planning, helping teams make smarter decisions without heavy IT reliance. Built on a high-performance Spark engine with machine learning-based resource management, multi-cloud support, and a tables-based architecture, Prism Analytics is designed to scale—supporting 1.1M monthly users, 30M queries, and 215T processed data rows. ## Overall experience with Workday Prism Analytics. #### Prism Eases Data Collection but Struggles with Data Integration into Workday. Prism is a powerful tool, it can be a bit confusing and mysterious as an easily misunderstood system but it makes it easy to collect and map data to Workday systems... ## Likes and dislikes about Workday Prism Analytics. Allows a quick mass drop of immense amount of data into a repository that allows us to end the lifecycle with other systems and take our time mapping archaic data into Workday to ensure we have a great view of historical information that precedes the date of usage of Workday ...... While in concept it is powerful, there is a degree of inflexibility when it comes to pushing data from Prism into core. It is a bit confusing as to exactly what the best way of loading data into the system is in order to reduce the time it takes for us to circulate the data in Workday...",
      "score": 0.46497503,
      "raw_content": null
    },
    {

      "url": "https://www.bloomberg.com/news/newsletters/2026-01-15/anthropic-gets-a-viral-moment-with-cowork-tool-built-mostly-by-ai",
      "title": "Anthropic Gets a Viral Moment With Cowork Tool Built ...",
      "content": "For Anthropic, the product’s early traction could eventually pave the way for more business customers, expanding on the momentum the OpenAI rival has seen from Claude Code, which reached a $1 billion revenue run rate in just six months. Cowork also points to a new era when people with little to no coding experience can quickly create a viable product, raising doubts about other specialized software products. Shares of Salesforce, Workday, Autodesk and other firms all slipped after Anthropic’s announcement. [...] LEARN MORE\n\n## Most Read\n\n Taiwan Wants to Arrest OnePlus CEO in Latest Step to Block China\n US Mortgage Rates Slide to One of Lowest Levels Since 2022\n Silver Falls After Trump Holds Off on Critical Mineral Tariffs\n Stocks Get AI Boost as Small Caps Keep Rallying: Markets Wrap\n Amazon Loses First Attempt to Block Saks Bankruptcy Funding\n\nBefore it's here, it's on the Bloomberg Terminal\n\nLEARN MORE\n\nHomeBTV+Market DataOpinionAudioOriginalsMagazineEvents\n\nMarketsEconomicsTechnologyPoliticsGreenCryptoAI\n\nWork & Life\n\nWealthPursuitsBusinessweekCityLabSportsEqualityManagement & Work\n\nMarket Data\n\nStocksCommoditiesRates & BondsCurrenciesFuturesSectorsEconomic Calendar\n\nNewslettersExplainersPointed News QuizAlphadots GameThe Big TakeGraphicsSubmit a TipAbout Us\n\nGet unlimited access today. [...] “The industry is changing a little bit,” Rieseberg said. “In the past, execution used to be extremely expensive. We have this interesting inflection point where the decisions that we make and the product thinking is probably the difficult part. We can very quickly actually do the engineering.”   \n  \nStill, Rieseberg said AI coding isn’t quite as automated as it seems on the surface. “It’s not just like we go into a dark corner and say, ‘Claude, build a new product,’ and then a week later, it’s launched,” he said. “Humans are in the loop for us. Humans review all the code.”",

[...] Preview\n\n- [x] \n\nSubscribe \n\n  \n\nIn an age where it has become harder than ever for prominent people to control the use of their own image and likeness, more are now opting to put out their own AI chatbots.\n\nRobbins, the motivational speaker and life coach, unveiled his AI coaching app in February, based on his talks, books and interviews, for $99 a month. (He later sued companies that used his name and image for chatbots without authorization.)\n\nAuthor and relationship coach Matthew Hussey runs “Matthew AI,” a voice-and-text chatbot that talks to people in his voice for $39 a month. Matthew AI—which is available 24/7 and speaks in dozens of languages—has had over a million conversations since it launched in 2024, Hussey said.\n\n  \n\n1.9 million",

According to a recent Workday blog, today contingent workers make up roughly 30% of the total workforce in financial services, and that share is projected to rise to 50% within the next few years. [...] ## Continuous innovation and industry alignment\n\nAs part of the broader Workday ecosystem, VNDLY benefits from the same continuous innovation model that underpins Workday’s cloud applications. The platform is regularly enhanced in collaboration with clients to help address emerging needs in services procurement, statement of work (SOW) management, and reporting depth—areas of particular importance in the financial services sector.\n\nThis commitment to client-led innovation helps make sure that VNDLY evolves in parallel with the complex regulatory and operational demands of the industry. For financial institutions, it means future-ready functionality that scales as workforce strategies mature.\n\n## From cost control to competitive advantage",

      "url": "https://vendordirectory.shrm.org/company/937808/news/3747252/data-driven-compensation-planning-tool-how-hr-teams-can-move-beyond-spreadsheets",
      "title": "Data-Driven Compensation Planning Tool: How HR Teams ...",
      "content": "Market Pricing Capabilities\n\nMarket pricing capabilities should enable HR teams to quickly benchmark any role against current U.S. market conditions.  Users select specific job titles, experience levels, and geographic locations—whether San Francisco Bay Area, Denver metro, Atlanta region, or fully remote U.S.—and retrieve current percentile data for base salary, total cash compensation, and equity packages. AI-assisted job matching helps align internal position titles with external benchmarks, particularly valuable for hybrid roles like “DevOps Engineer with AI/ML focus” or “Revenue Operations Analyst” that span traditional job family boundaries. [...] Turnkey integrations with major HRIS and payroll systems—including Workday, UKG, ADP, SAP SuccessFactors, Oracle, BambooHR, and Rippling—enable automated data flows rather than manual uploads each cycle.\n Single sign-on support through common identity providers like Okta and Azure AD ensures seamless access while maintaining security standards.\n The ability to import existing survey data from providers like Mercer, Radford, ERI, and Culpepper protects previous investments while enabling gradual transition to real-time datasets. [...] Modern real-time datasets offer granular segmentation by detailed job titles, job families, experience levels, and U.S. metropolitan areas or broader regional clusters. Advanced platforms like SalaryCube’s Bigfoot Live provide daily-updated benchmarks with transparent methodology documentation and sample size disclosure, ensuring HR teams can evaluate data quality and make defendable decisions. The ability to price hybrid or emerging roles through AI-assisted job matching addresses the growing challenge of compensation benchmarking for positions that don’t fit traditional survey categories.\n\nInternal HRIS and Payroll Data\n\nInternal HRIS and payroll data must flow automatically into planning workflows rather than requiring manual uploads each cycle.  Essential data streams include:",

      "content": "Financial services is one vertical where customers have realised the imperative of the move, she says. She says if a customer isn’t speaking to SAP about the move, it may well be too late to get a system installed before the cut-off date.\n\n“We’re prioritising helping those who are speaking to us to make that decision. We have to work with every customer individually to understand how they can do that transformation. There are different routes, based on capacity, budget and risk appetite. If you delay a decision, it’s going to be too late.” [...] All this became obsolete with the introduction of ERP systems, “because now all that stuff is in the SAP system”. “There’s an application, and you click on it, and it scans the database and pays the overdue suppliers, given the payment terms and the contractual agreements. Accountants still exist and have more work than ever before, but they just do an entirely different job. A lot of the work that is being done today, in accruals, for example, will go away, but there is so much more work that they can do, because the world is getting more complex.\n\n“There are tons of challenges that we can solve. And it will allow humans to move on and really use what humans are good at, which is to design the next level of the evolution of history, based on AI.” [...] “We provide AI in the toolchain, to help the customer convert the custom code, to either get rid of it, or convert it, so there’s a clean core, with compliant code. presents AI-driven responses |\n| Agent Orchestration | Coordinates the agent workflow and execution sequence |\n| AI Core | Executes the agent runtime with policy enforcement |\n| LLM Call (via GenAI Hub) | Performs language reasoning using governed model access |\n| Short-Term Memory | Maintains session context and intermediate results |\n| Grounding | Retrieves enterprise context and Top-K evidence for accuracy |\n| Long-Term Memory | Provides access to business data, documents, and vectors |\n| Agent Proposes Tool Call | Determines the next business action to execute | [...] |  |  |\n --- |\n| Execution Mechanism | Purpose |\n| SAP APIs | Invoke business operations in SAP applications such as S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, and other SAP services |\n| Joule Skills | Encapsulate reusable business actions that can be triggered through Joule |\n| Function Calling | Enable structured invocation of predefined actions based on AI decisions |\n| Model Context Protocol (MCP) Servers | Open standard providing standardized context and tool interfaces for AI-driven execution (governed via AI Agent Hub in SAP LeanIX) |\n| Agent-to-Agent (A2A) Interaction | Industry protocol enabling coordinated actions across multiple specialized agents |\n| SAP Build Process Automation (BPA) | Trigger workflows and business processes requiring orchestration or approvals | [...] |  |  |\n --- |\n| Governance Component | Purpose |\n| AI Agent Hub in SAP LeanIX | Central visibility and governance of AI agents and their relationships |\n| Joule Studio | Design-time configuration and management of Joule skills and AI interactions |\n| AI Launchpad | Model lifecycle management, versioning, and approval workflows |\n| Model Registry | Central inventory of approved AI models and configurations |\n| Data Privacy Integration | Enforcement of data protection and privacy controls across AI usage |\n| Audit Log Service | Centralized logging of AI actions for auditability and compliance |\n| Human-in-the-Loop Controls | Approval gates for sensitive or high-risk AI-driven actions |\n\nCross-Cutting Controls: Security, Privacy, and Observability",

      "url": "https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/what-s-new-in-sap-automation-pilot-h2-2025/ba-p/14302099",
      "title": "What's New in SAP Automation Pilot H2 2025",
      "content": "### No-Code MCP Servers Powered by SAP Automation Pilot\n\nSAP Automation Pilot now allows you to create Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers using no-code and low-code tools. These MCP servers expose SAP Automation Pilot commands and workflows as tools that can be consumed by AI agents, including those built with Joule Studio.\n\nThis makes it possible for agents to securely trigger automations, retrieve system state, and perform remediation actions using governed SAP Automation Pilot capabilities, instead of relying on ad-hoc scripts or unsecured endpoints.\n\nLearn more:\n\n Integrating SAP Automation Pilot with AI Agents\n Agent builder in Joule Studio is now generally available: Build your own Joule agents today!\n\n## Extending Automation into Hybrid Landscapes [...] ## How to stay tuned to recent and upcoming innovations?\n\n What’s New in SAP Automation Pilot\n SAP Road Map Explorer for SAP Automation Pilot.\n Release Navigator for SAP Automation Pilot - helping you easily find product release notes, blog posts, and related web pages.\n Public GitHub SAP Automation Pilot sample use cases;\n\nLabels \n\n Product Updates​\n Technology Updates​\n\n agentic\n AI Agents\n GenAI\n joule studio\n mcp\n SAP Automation Pilot\n SAP Cloud ALM\n sap cloud connector\n\n  \n\nYou must be a registered user to add a comment.       "title": "AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026) — The Change Manag...",
      "content": "AI in SuccessFactors typically shows up in three layers:\n\n Digital assistant experience (Joule): a “front door” to ask, navigate, and get guided support across workflows. Users need permission to access it (for example, “Access to Joule” in RBP).\n Embedded AI in modules: AI-assisted experiences inside Recruiting, Learning, Performance, and other areas (depending on scope/entitlements).\n Extensibility (Joule Studio): the layer (via SAP Build) to create and manage custom Joule agents/skills for your organization, including SAP and non-SAP workflows.\n\nThis blog is not about “turning it on.” It is about making AI stick through trust, enablement, and manager-led reinforcement.\n\n## 1) Make adoption a workstream (not a side activity) [...] Now Part 2 goes where most programs struggle: change management - including how to enable frontline managers to confidently handle human-in-the-loop responsibilities (reviewing AI output, validating key facts, and owning final decisions). In 2026, AI in HR has moved beyond pilots; organizations are wiring AI into everyday SuccessFactors workflows through Joule and embedded capabilities. The teams that win won’t be the ones that merely “turn on” AI - they’ll be the ones that treat adoption as a product: clear outcomes, clear boundaries, and a manager-led reinforcement model.\n\n## What you’ll get in this blog [...] 10 hours ago\n\n1  Like\n\n5,453\n\n SAP Managed Tags\n SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite\n Joule\n SAP Business AI\n Joule Studio\n\n SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite\n\n  SAP SuccessFactors HCM\n Joule\n\n  Additional Software Product\n SAP Business AI\n\n  Software Product\n Joule Studio\n\n  Software Product Function\n\nView products (4)\n\n# AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026) — The Change Management Blueprint\n\nPart 2 of the “Practical Implementation Blueprint” series",

      "url": "https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/my-highlights-of-the-sap-cloud-erp-2602-release/ba-p/14304712",
      "title": "My highlights of the SAP Cloud ERP 2602 release",
      "content": "These capabilities are enabled by blueprint-based provisioning, which changes how solution instances are deployed, integrated, and managed across the run phase. Instead of manual setup, customers can activate selective solutions or in the future complete suites that are provisioned and come already fully integrated together. Guided by a new suite experience in SAP for Me and based on SAP landscape modeling best practices, SAP applies a desired-state-based reconciliation to ensure transparency, consistency, and long-term stability across the application landscape.\n\n### AI innovations\n\n#### SAP Joule for Consultants: Practical enhancements for your everyday project work [...] In Asset Management, keeping maintenance processes running smoothly depends on timely and accurate notifications, often created under time pressure and by users outside of specialized maintenance roles. With Joule integrated into the maintenance notification process in SAP Cloud ERP, creating and screening notifications becomes more straightforward and accessible. Users can describe an issue in natural language and capture key details such as the technical object, priority, and description without navigating complex transaction flows. Moreover, users can access notifications in the ‘Manage Maintenance Notification’ SAP Fiori app (F5777), enabling quick acceptance and conversion into maintenance orders within a single conversational context. As a result, operators spend less time on [...] In the area of Retail, Joule’s integration into assortment module management supports planners by making common tasks more accessible and less time-consuming. Instead of navigating multiple screens, users can rely on natural language interactions to create, update, or terminate assortments directly within the application. This reduces dependency on deep technical knowledge and helps teams complete routine tasks with greater confidence and efficiency. As a result, merchandising and category managers can spend less time on operational steps and more time focusing on assortment strategy and customer-centric planning.\n\nFor more information, please consult SAP Help Portal.\n\n### \n\n### Asset Management\n\n### Maintenance notification creation and screening with Joule",

MCP provides a standardized way for AI agents to \"browse\" your external data safely.\n Real-time Execution: It enables Agentic AI—meaning the AI can trigger an action in a 3rd party system based on a command given in the SAP UI.\n\nSAP Joule and Microsoft Copilot OOTB integration\n\nA primary example (Refer Pic above) of this is SAP Joule and Microsoft Copilot integration (refer Discovery center link here)\n\n3. Through Joule Studio (which utilizes AI Foundation Services), we are now moving into the era of AI Agents.\n\nC.Data:The data layer provides SAP’s business data fabric and semantic models, enabling AI to understand business objects rather than raw tables. When asked what distinguishes Slackbot from these alternatives, Seaman pointed to context and convenience. [...] Looking ahead, Harris expects the interfaces themselves to evolve beyond pure conversation. \"We're kind of saturating what we can do with purely conversational UIs,\" he said. \"I think we'll start to see agents building an interface that best suits your intent, as opposed to trying to surface something within a conversational interface that matches your intent.\"\n\nMicrosoft, Google, and a growing roster of AI startups are placing similar bets — that the winning enterprise AI will be the one embedded in the tools workers already use, not another application to learn. The race to become that invisible layer of workplace intelligence is now fully underway. [...] The new Slackbot, now generally available to Business+ and Enterprise+ customers, is Salesforce's most aggressive move yet to position Slack at the center of the emerging \"agentic AI\" movement — where software agents work alongside humans to complete complex tasks. The launch comes as Salesforce attempts to convince investors that artificial intelligence will bolster its products rather than render them obsolete.\n\n\"Slackbot isn't just another copilot or AI assistant,\" said Parker Harris, Salesforce co-founder and Slack's chief technology officer, in an exclusive interview with Salesforce. \"It's the front door to the agentic enterprise, powered by Salesforce.\"\n\n## From tricycle to Porsche: Salesforce rebuilt Slackbot from the ground up",
