      "content": "“The biggest hurdle is not understanding the platform, and actually, the tool set in most platforms is pretty simple,” says Matt Grippo, SVP of core software at Workday. “The part that takes a little bit more knowledge is understanding the environment, the security model, and the business processes you have to work with.”\n\nWith LLMs and agentic AI capabilities being introduced by SaaS and low-code development platforms, developers may be considering whether learning them is a smart career path. [...] ## Diving into SaaS and low-code development\n\nSome developers have staked their careers on building skills and delivering results from enterprise SaaS platforms. On the other hand, some developers have focused on pro-code development and open source frameworks, leaving low-code and proprietary platforms aside.\n\nDevelopers should cast a wide net when learning to increase job opportunities and be open-minded about platforms, especially if they want to work in large enterprises. Some enterprise SaaS platforms with extended development capabilities include SAP, Salesforce, and Workday. Here’s a primer on the breadth of their development capabilities.\n\nDevelopers should also consider learning enterprise-ready low-code platforms that embrace AI, such as Appian, OutSystems, Pega, and Quickbase. [...] Developers must also explore how to use generative AI tools to write agile requirements, develop software, automate testing, maintain documentation, and drive other efficiencies across the software development life cycle (SDLC). Developer experiences are evolving from IDEs focused on writing code to natural language dialogs, code validation tools, and AI agents performing development tasks.\n\n“AI SDLC tools are just another new way for developers to use powerful assistants in their development pipelines, much like the modern IDE,” says Simon Margolis, associate CTO of AI and machine learning at SADA. “The developer’s core goal doesn’t change: applying logic to command tools, whether using English and Gemini CLI or writing Python directly.”\n\n## Diving into SaaS and low-code development",

GenAI becomes more immersive with the introduction of digital assistants that are part of business processes to assist human workers and (4) the ‘Evolve’ phase makes enterprises fully GenAI-enabled, with employees collaboratively working with digital assistants and AI agents, leveraging both internal and curated external data for real-time, intelligent decision-making. [...] GenAI can assist code generation and review, helping to address skills shortages and improve alignment between implementations and stated requirements. It can help build granular knowledge bases, reduce manual data processing by reimagining workflows as human-agent collaboration, broaden ecosystems through open innovation in cloud and distributed computing, and elevate architecture and integration by exposing AI as services within and beyond the enterprise, including to regulators. Broader implications include greater personalisation, support for sustainability goals, and improved digital resilience (for example through alignment with the EU Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) framework).\n\n## Illustrative example: Evolving account transfers with GenAI [...] This figure illustrates the four phases of enterprise GenAI adoption: (1) Experimentation, where organisations explore GenAI’s suitability for specific domains, processes, or use cases through proof-of-value initiatives like productivity improvement in SDLC activities; (2) Prepare, where enterprises use GenAI to prepare for modernisation by building knowledge repositories using legacy code bases and address challenges in modernisation. The Prepare phase includes AI for IT use cases like code documentation, test case generation, API enablement of legacy assets, etc, and AI for business use cases like chatbots, copilots for frontline workers. (3) In the Transform phase, knowledge repositories from the preparation phase are used to build target applications in cloud. GenAI becomes more",

      "content": "All Posts\n\n# Salesforce rolls out new Slackbot AI agent as it battles Microsoft and Google in workplace AI\n\nMichael Nuñez\n\nSalesforce on Tuesday launched an entirely rebuilt version of Slackbot, the company's workplace assistant, transforming it from a simple notification tool into what executives describe as a fully powered AI agent capable of searching enterprise data, drafting documents, and taking action on behalf of employees. [...] Other pilot customers include Slalom, reMarkable, Xero, Mercari, and Engine. Mollie Bodensteiner, SVP of Operations at Engine, called Slackbot \"an absolute 'chaos tamer' for our team,\" estimating it saves her about 30 minutes daily \"just by eliminating context switching.\"\n\n## Slackbot vs. Microsoft Copilot vs. Google Gemini: The fight for enterprise AI dominance\n\nThe launch puts Salesforce in direct competition with Microsoft's Copilot, which is integrated into Teams and the broader Microsoft 365 suite, as well as Google's Gemini integrations across Workspace. When asked what distinguishes Slackbot from these alternatives, Seaman pointed to context and convenience. [...] Madrigal said his security team signed off \"rather quickly\" — unusual for enterprise AI deployments — because Slackbot accesses only the information each individual user already has permission to view. \"Given all the guardrails you guys have put into place for Slackbot to be unique and customized to only the information that each individual user has, only the conversations and the Slack rooms and Slack channels that they're part of—that made my security team sign off rather quickly.\"\n\nOne Beast Industries employee, Sinan, the head of Beast Games marketing, reported saving \"at bare minimum, 90 minutes a day.\" Another employee, Spencer, a creative supervisor, described it as \"an assistant who's paying attention when I'm not.\"",

      "url": "http://mckinsey.com/capabilities/tech-and-ai/our-insights/superagency-in-the-workplace-empowering-people-to-unlock-ais-full-potential-at-work",
      "title": "AI in the workplace: A report for 2025 | McKinsey",
      "content": "In many transformations, employees are not ready for change, but AI is different. Employee readiness and familiarity are high, which gives business leaders the permission space to act. Leaders can listen to employees describe how they are using AI today and how they envision their work being transformed. They also can provide employees with much-needed training and empower managers to move AI use cases from pilot to scale.\n\nIt’s critical that leaders meet this moment. It’s the only way to accelerate the probability that their companies will reach AI maturity. But they must move with alacrity, or they will fall behind.\n\nChapter 3\n\n## Delivering speed and safety [...] Imagine a world where machines not only perform physical labor but also think, learn, and make autonomous decisions. This world includes humans in the loop, bringing people and machines together in a state of superagency that increases personal productivity and creativity (see sidebar “AI superagency”). This is the transformative potential of AI, a technology with a potential impact poised to surpass even the biggest innovations of the past, from the printing press to the automobile. AI does not just automate tasks but goes further by automating cognitive functions. Unlike any invention before, AI-powered software can adapt, plan, guide—and even make—decisions. That’s why AI can be a catalyst for unprecedented economic growth and societal change in virtually every aspect of life. It will [...] The analysis extended far beyond surveys. The researchers also conducted interviews with dozens of C-level executives and industry experts to understand their perspectives on AI’s transformative potential and the steps they are taking to lead their organizations through this transition. The report was further enriched by discussions with experts at Stanford HAI, the Digital Economy Lab at HAI, and McKinsey’s leading AI experts. Our survey and research primarily focus on gen AI; however, it is important to note that participants in the survey may not have consistently differentiated between gen AI and other forms of AI.",

      "url": "https://www.mercer.com/en-us/insights/us-health-news/unlocking-the-power-of-benefits-data-and-ai/",
      "title": "Unlocking the power of benefits data and AI",
      "content": "Furthermore, automating routine tasks through AI — such as eligibility verification, claims processing, and reporting — reduces administrative burdens and minimizes errors. This not only improves efficiency but also frees HR teams to focus on strategic initiatives like employee engagement and benefits design.\n\nPredicting employee behavior and needs\n\nOne of AI’s most powerful applications is its ability to forecast employee needs. The employee benefits lifecycle is not a new concept but understanding it remains crucial. Employees’ needs evolve over time, from first job benefits to retirement planning. For example, younger employees may focus on student debt and early career development, while those in their 50s and 60s are more concerned with healthcare and retirement options. [...] Enrollment patterns, claims data, utilization rates and demographic details provide a comprehensive picture of employee preferences and behaviors. When analyzed effectively,  this data can inform strategic decisions that enhance employee experience and operational efficiency and point the way to cost savings. For example, if data indicates a rising interest in mental health resources, employers can expand relevant offerings, demonstrating responsiveness and care. Similarly, AI can reveal which benefits are underutilized and not providing value, helping employers optimize investments by negotiating better rates, eliminating redundant coverage, or streamlining plan options [...] Employer considerations\n\nMany employers are not yet leveraging AI in their total rewards processes. This gap presents a significant opportunity to harness AI’s potential to improve decision-making and employee experience. To maximize the power of your benefits data, consider the following:\n\nThe future of benefits management is data-driven and AI-enabled. Organizations that embrace AI will be better positioned to predict employee needs, personalize rewards, and operate more efficiently. This approach not only enhances employee satisfaction and retention but also drives cost savings through smarter resource allocation and process automation. Your journey begins with data readiness and a willingness to innovate.\n\nCoworkers standing up and looking at tablet together",

      "title": "AI in the workplace: A report for 2025 | McKinsey",
      "content": "AI is the latest in a series of transformative supertools, including the steam engine, internet, and smartphone, that have reshaped our world by amplifying human capabilities. Like its predecessors, AI can democratize access to knowledge and automate tasks, assuming humans can develop and deploy it safely and equitably. [...] Imagine a world where machines not only perform physical labor but also think, learn, and make autonomous decisions. This world includes humans in the loop, bringing people and machines together in a state of superagency that increases personal productivity and creativity (see sidebar “AI superagency”). This is the transformative potential of AI, a technology with a potential impact poised to surpass even the biggest innovations of the past, from the printing press to the automobile. AI does not just automate tasks but goes further by automating cognitive functions. Unlike any invention before, AI-powered software can adapt, plan, guide—and even make—decisions. That’s why AI can be a catalyst for unprecedented economic growth and societal change in virtually every aspect of life. It will [...] ### Multimodality is bringing together text, audio, and video\n\nToday’s AI models are evolving toward more advanced and diverse data processing capabilities across text, audio, and video. Over the last two years, we have seen improvements in the quality of each modality. For example, Google’s Gemini Live has improved audio quality and latency and can now deliver a human-like conversation with emotional nuance and expressiveness.10Ivan Solovyev and Shrestha Basu Mallick, “Gemini 2.0: Level up your apps with real-time multimodal interactions,” Google, December 23, 2024.       "title": "Joule Copilot from SAP | Artificial Intelligence",
      "content": ":   Joule uses generative AI to respond to the intent of user questions and requests expressed in natural language. Joule determines how to respond by combining the user’s intent with rich context about their business role and the SAP applications and data that run business processes. Joule uses skills and collaborative AI agents to complete tasks, reveal insights, and autonomously perform multistep workflows using generative AI. [...] Read the blog post\n\n## Frequently asked questions\n\n:   An AI copilot is a virtual assistant that uses a conversational interface to help users of business applications complete tasks more efficiently. Copilots use generative AI and other technologies to understand user requests, perform actions, and provide insights based on business data. Compared to earlier digital assistants, AI copilots provide a more human-like conversational experience and a broader and more flexible range of capabilities. [...] Pre-integrated with your trusted business data and existing business applications.\n Infused with business context to reason and act reliably across your business.\n Accessed through role-based AI assistants for a simple and intuitive AI experience.\n\n### Free your teams from busy work and empower them to:\n\n Work more efficiently to get more done, faster.\n Automate mundane tasks to focus on more strategic, high-impact work.\n Achieve more productive collaboration that drives better outcomes.\n\n### Empower every employee to ask complex questions and receive deeply researched answers to:",

The speed gained through AI's time savings \"doesn't always translate into better outcomes.\" At least 85% of employees report saving one to seven hours per week using AI. However, the follow-up rework required washes out the savings -- to the tune of an average 1.5 weeks a year spent fixing AI outputs, the survey analysts estimate. Only 14% of employees consistently achieve net-positive outcomes from AI use, they add.\n\nAlso:Your colleagues are sick of your AI workslop [...] That's the lesson being learned among employees and executives responding to a new survey by Workday. While AI is delivering productivity gains, those gains are being partially washed away when technologists or employees need to go back to implementations to fix mistakes, rewrite content, or double-check outputs. At least 37% of time savings gained through AI are lost to fixing low-quality output, according to the survey's authors, which included the experiences of 3,200 practitioners.\n\n## The ultimate AI productivity paradox",

      "url": "https://www.zdnet.com/article/ai-could-eliminate-boredom-value-busy-work/",
      "title": "Is AI's war on busywork a creativity killer? What the experts ...",
      "content": "\"There's a risk in assuming that every recovered minute should be filled with more high-intensity work,\" she said. \"If teams are constantly pushed from one cognitively demanding task to the next, creativity and strategic clarity actually suffer … AI should not turn the workday into a nonstop sprint, [but] rather create a better rhythm.\"\n\nAn overreliance on AI tools in the workplace also raises the risk of creating a fractured, lonely workplace. [...] ## 'AI should not turn the workday into a nonstop sprint'\n\nAnother central problem with the AI industry's sales pitch is that even the most productive, disciplined workers can't sustain intensely focused work indefinitely. We all have creative peaks and valleys over the course of a day; the trick is for each of us to get to know our own particular cognitive rhythms and learn to work with them.\n\nTo believe that we can simply offload busywork onto AI and perpetually focus on more cognitively demanding work is to misunderstand our own minds. [...] \"I suspect that if we optimized entirely for highly cognitive work, we'd run into diminishing returns on quality,\" said Shawn Spooner, global chief technology officer at advertising agency Billups. \"A better paradigm would be to aim to keep our folks in flow state for a few multi-hour blocks each day, where they are the most productive and the most happy, stitched together with more mundane tasks to give their day a more natural ebb and flow.\"\n\nAlso: 3 ways anyone can start using AI at work today - safely\n\nDebra Andrews, president of consulting firm Marketri, echoed that idea that the optimal workday is one that harmonizes hyper-focused productivity with relaxed downtime.",

Aware that artificial intelligence isn’t going away, they have accepted that AI will be increasingly interwoven into everything they do — at work and at home. Try as they might to despise this inevitable encroachment, many people are feeling a sense of excitement about exploring the technology and discovering what it can do.\n\nAI apprehension crosses generations",

      "title": "What are ambient agents? Why AI that acts will redefine ...",
      "content": "It really comes down to whether the company is cloud-forward and already invested in automation. Keith: That makes sense. But I can hear IT folks asking: “Is this just another tool to bolt onto our existing stack?” How easy is integration? Bhavin: Ambient agents are challenging the current model.\n\nCopilots today mostly enhance the platform they live in — like Salesforce or Microsoft. But ambient agents work across systems — Slack, Workday, Jira, ServiceNow. That requires more expansive integration but delivers far more value. Fortunately, platforms are becoming more extensible, which helps. [...] Back \n\nPolicies\n\n   Terms of Service\n   Privacy Policy\n   Cookie Policy\n   Copyright Notice\n   Member Preferences\n   About AdChoices\n   Your California Privacy Rights\n\n Back \n\nOur Network\n\n   CIO\n   CSO\n   InfoWorld\n   Network World\n\n Back \n\nMore\n\n   News\n   Features\n   Opinion\n   Blogs\n   BrandPosts\n   Events\n   Podcasts\n   Videos\n   Enterprise Buyer’s Guides\n\n1.   Home\n2.   Videos\n3.   Today in Tech\n4.   What are ambient agents? Why AI that acts will redefine automation at work\n\n Today in Tech \n\n Host Keith Shaw and his expert guests discuss the latest technology news and trends happening in the industry. Watch new episodes twice each week here or listen to the podcast. \n\nWhat are ambient agents? Why AI that acts will redefine automation at work [...] Keith: But that also raises privacy and security concerns. How do you manage trust and access? Bhavin: Privacy and autonomy are top of mind. Agents must respect the same enterprise rules already in place — no “god mode” access. You can’t have an agent guessing access permissions.\n\nAccess must be deterministic, based on roles, ACLs, and existing policies. Autonomy is earned over time. We advise starting with low-risk actions, like password resets. Only later should agents handle more sensitive tasks.\n\nKeith: And if trust is built, users are more willing to give up control — especially if the agent reassures them it can restore access quickly. Bhavin: Exactly. The key is reducing friction.",

      "url": "https://www.pwc.com/us/en/library/case-studies/pwc-microsoft-copilot-enterprise-ai.html",
      "title": "PwC deploys Microsoft Copilot at enterprise scale",
      "content": "During the month of October 2025, PwC employees executed over 8.7 million actions in Copilot, freeing up over 500,000 hours of capacity in the process. With 54% of PwC’s global workforce using AI tools weekly, employees average nine prompts per week.\n\nThe impact extends beyond productivity. AI agents now help research teams extract data from complex files in seconds, freeing PwC employees to focus on higher-value insights. Citizen developers are creating low-code applications that further automate and improve processes.\n\nRole-based training helps employees understand how to use agents effectively, spot AI hallucinations, and apply Responsible AI principles in their daily work. Regular playbooks, live demos, and “prompt-of-the-day” campaigns continue to drive engagement. [...] ### 8.7M+\n\nCopilot Actions during the month of October 2025\n\nWe’re embedding AI across our business so our teams can unlock new value, act with confidence, and stay ahead.\n\nSITUATION\n\n## Building an intelligent foundation for the future of work\n\nThe true power of artificial intelligence (AI) isn’t efficiency—it’s empowering people to think, decide, and act with greater insight. As AI extends deeper into organizations, it unlocks new capabilities. But its real impact comes when people can use it to make faster, smarter, and more informed decisions. [...] SOLUTION\n\n## Embedding AI securely and at scale\n\nTransitioning to an AI-powered platform like Microsoft Copilot brought both opportunity and responsibility. We knew success meant more than introducing new tools—it required embedding AI into everyday workflows while protecting data and upholding strong governance. Copilot meets our teams where they already work, integrated into familiar Microsoft applications and tuned to our context, so AI can feel like a natural extension of daily tasks.",

      "url": "https://www.workday.com/en-hk/customer-stories/i-p/johnson-electric-explores-future-hr-era-genai.html",
      "title": "Johnson Electric Explores the Future of HR in the Era of Gen AI | Workday HK",
      "content": "## Boosting HR speed, precision, and intelligence.\n\n“Once Workday became our backbone of HR work globally, the next step was starting to use AI to make our lives easier,” says Moeller. For example, administrative HR tasks have been automated for years, but embedded AI now tells users when they make a mistake. Meanwhile Gen AI has taken over the task of creating job descriptions and postings, producing quality listings and adverts in seconds.\n\nAn advanced, AI-powered compensation module enables the team to automatically manage complex global requirements, from administering multiple bonus schemes to running diverse merit programs. The use of standardized rules gives Moeller confidence that employees are rewarded accurately and fairly, no matter where they are in the world. [...] Embedded AI suggests opportunities for improvement\n\nWhen Christian Moeller joined Johnson Electric as chief human resources officer, the company had been using Workday Human Capital Management (HCM) for three years. Moeller was there to see the system evolve to include AI tools. “It’s been a very fruitful partnership, full of mutual benefit,” Moeller notes. “Sometimes, we tell Workday what we need and Workday delivers. Sometimes Workday says, ‘Hey, we have this new functionality!’ and they show us how to use it.”\n\nJohnson Electric is already at the point where Workday is its only source of people data, integrated with finance and feeding all downstream systems. Now, under Moeller’s leadership, HR is exploring how the AI-powered Workday platform can enhance ways to work across the globe. [...] With generative AI capabilities embedded into its global HR platform, Johnson Electric is starting to accelerate work, drive continuous improvement, and uncover hidden talent in its 30,000-strong workforce.\n\nRecruitment ads and job descriptions written in seconds\n\nIntegrated people and finance data feed downstream systems\n\nEmbedded AI suggests opportunities for improvement",

      "url": "https://www.accenture.com/ma-en/case-studies/technology/continuous-reinvention-powered-with-workday",
      "title": "Accenture's HR Transformation with Workday: Embracing Gen AI",
      "content": "And with generative AI (gen AI), the opportunity is greater than ever. According to Accenture’s Work, Workforce, Workers research, 94% of people are ready to learn new skills to work with gen AI, yet only 5% of organizations are actively reskilling their workforce at scale. At a time when speed matters more than ever, Workday is a critical backbone enabling us to target, train and track the skills – from gen AI, to people leadership, to specialized industry skills – of all our people. [...] ## Powering up your people.\n\nWhen you have data everywhere, you have data nowhere. So, we made an early decision that all people data would be centralized in Workday.\n\nThis commitment simplified and personalized their experience in several ways. No more hunting for information across multiple systems—everything is in Workday. Additionally, the platform lets us focus on people’s skills, not just roles. Personalized career dashboards allow people to update information, highlight skills, explore opportunities, and connect with colleagues. As we transform our own workforce to work with gen AI and not be tethered to rigid jobs and roles, these insights are invaluable to accelerate our reinvention. [...] Resilient organizations are agile enough to continuously reinvent themselves in today’s shifting landscape, powered by their people. We know this because we have been on the journey ourselves, putting people at the center of our business strategy. We partnered with Workday to unleash our talent potential and prepare people for, not only a gen AI-enabled future, but for whatever is next on the horizon. Over the past four years, Workday has enabled us to continuously reinvent our business and talent models, unlock talent potential, innovate for our people, and make faster strategic decisions. [...] ## Powering up your people.\n\nWhen you have data everywhere, you have data nowhere. No more hunting for information across multiple systems—everything is in Workday. Additionally, the platform lets us focus on people’s skills, not just roles. Personalized career dashboards allow people to update information, highlight skills, explore opportunities, and connect with colleagues. As we transform our own workforce to work with gen AI and not be tethered to rigid jobs and roles, these insights are invaluable to accelerate our reinvention. [...] Resilient organizations are agile enough to continuously reinvent themselves in today’s shifting landscape, powered by their people. We know this because we have been on the journey ourselves, putting people at the center of our business strategy. We partnered with Workday to unleash our talent potential and prepare people for, not only a gen AI-enabled future, but for whatever is next on the horizon. Over the past four years, Workday has enabled us to continuously reinvent our business and talent models, unlock talent potential, innovate for our people, and make faster strategic decisions. The columns represent age groups: 18-24, 25-34, 35-44, 45-54, 55-64, and 65+. The data is presented as percentages of respondents who agreed with each sentiment within each age group. [...] Exhibit 14\n\nImage description begins:\n\nThe exhibit is made up of a scatter plot and a separate bar chart visualizing the relationship between the potential economic value from gen AI and the share of employees with a positive outlook on gen AI, categorized by business function. The exhibit illustrates that the functions with the employees most optimistic about gen AI are not the functions with the greatest potential economic value from gen AI. [...] Exhibit 3\n\nImage description begins:\n\nThe first section of the exhibit is a horizontal bar chart showing the percentage of US employees who believe that specific company initiatives would increase their daily use of gen AI tools. Formal gen AI training from their organization scored highest at 48 percent, followed by seamless integration into existing workflows (45 percent), access to gen AI tools (41 percent), and incentives and rewards (40 percent). Lower percentages were observed for usage of gen AI being a requirement for a certification program (30 percent), explicit instructions from managers to use gen AI (30 percent), being involved in the development of the tools (29 percent), and OKRs/KPIs tied to gen AI usage (22 percent).",

Link Copied\n\nRemember the early days of agentic AI? It felt like starting a garage band with your friends. You messed around with fun tools, made some noise, and didn't worry about being perfect. It was exciting, chaotic, and low-stakes.\n\nBut in 2026, the jam sessions are over.\n\nNow it’s time to get practical. The wild excitement around AI is being replaced by a focus on what actually works. The goal has shifted from exploring what AI can do to proving what it should do for your business. We are trading the thrill of jam sessions for the discipline of clear rules and real profits. [...] ## 4. Fix the Feedback Loop (The \"Workslop\" Tax)\n\nLeaders are checking the receipts.\n\nAccording to Forrester, CEOs are expected to pull CFOs into more AI decisions this year, which might actually delay 25% of planned AI spending.\n\nWhy the hesitation? Because of a hidden cost called \"workslop.”\n\nWorkslop is the messy, low-quality output that bad AI creates. It sounds productive—your AI writes a report in seconds!—but then your human employees have to spend hours fixing the errors. Workday thinks of this as the “AI Tax.”\n\nAccording to Workday research, nearly 40% of AI’s promised productivity is silently lost to rework. For every 10 hours of time you save using AI, your team pays back four hours just fixing the output.",

In the current state, a credit or debit transfer request involves static validations like account checks and exception handling. In the future state, intelligent GenAI agents can enhance this process by dynamically leveraging external data, customer context, and market events. These agents can add contextual insights such as selecting the best account or currency, auto-handling exceptions (eg, fraud, AML, insufficient balance), and optimising transaction costs. This enables real-time decision-making, deeper personalisation, and more meaningful customer experience.       "url": "https://www.workday.com/pl-pl/resources/workday-demos.html",
      "title": "Prezentacje produktów Workday | Workday",
      "content": "### Poznaj możliwości Workday z bliska\n\nPrzyszłość pracy wymaga podejmowania pewnych decyzji, usprawnienia operacji biznesowych i finansowych oraz wsparcia pracowników. Przejrzyj wyselekcjonowaną kolekcję prezentacji i zobacz, jak nasza platforma AI dla przedsiębiorstw pomaga Ci to osiągnąć.\n\n### \n\n### Prezentacje rozwiązań finansowych\n\nPrzeglądaj więcej prezentacji\n\n#### Workday dla finansów\n\nPołącz dane finansowe i kadrowe, aby uzyskać informacje w czasie rzeczywistym, które pomogą Ci podejmować działanie.\n\nOdtwórz prezentację (2:21)\n\n#### Zarządzanie wydatkami dla działu zaopatrzenia\n\nZapewnij liderom działów finansów i zamówień wgląd w proces od zaopatrzenia do płatności.\n\nOdtwórz prezentację (3:13)\n\n#### Workday Adaptive Planning [...] #### Prezentacja platformy AI dla przedsiębiorstw\n\nZwiększ efektywność, uwolnij pełny potencjał danych i uprzedzaj zmiany dzięki AI.\n\nOdtwórz prezentację (3:08)\n\n#### Odkryj nową wartość dzięki Workday Extend\n\nTwórz nowe aplikacje na miarę swoich unikalnych potrzeb w zakresie finansów i kadr.\n\nOdtwórz prezentację (3:03)\n\n#### Interoperacyjność w handlu detalicznym\n\nUprość łączenie systemów i danych.\n\nOdtwórz prezentację (4:29)\n\n#### Uwolnij możliwości dostosowywania Workday\n\nDostosowuj się do zmian, takich jak przejęcia, zatrudnianie pracowników czy restrukturyzacja.\n\nOdtwórz prezentację (4:17)\n\n## Zobacz, jak zapewniamy szybkie i skuteczne wdrożenie.\n\nKontakt z działem sprzedaży\n\n##### Zaakceptuj pliki cookie, aby przejść dalej. [...] #### Usługi finansowe Workday\n\nRozwijaj pracowników, kontroluj koszty i zapewniaj sprawną obsługę klienta.\n\nOdtwórz prezentację (3:05)\n\n#### Workday Professional Services Automation\n\nDopasuj właściwych pracowników do odpowiednich projektów, zarządzaj budżetami i dostarczaj świetną rezultaty na czas.\n\nOdtwórz prezentację (3:05)\n\n#### Zarządzanie łańcuchem dostaw w opiece zdrowotnej\n\nPodejmuj lepsze decyzje i ograniczaj koszty w całym łańcuchu dostaw.\n\nOdtwórz prezentację (3:26)\n\n#### Workday Student\n\nPomóż uczącym się łatwo znajdować potrzebne informacje i wykonywać zadania w Workday.\n\nOdtwórz prezentację (2:46)\n\n### \n\n### Prezentacje platformy\n\nPrzeglądaj więcej prezentacji\n\n#### Prezentacja platformy AI dla przedsiębiorstw",

      "url": "https://www.wipro.com/newsroom/press-releases/2023/wipro-launches-wipro-ai360-commits-to-investing-1-billion-in-ai-over-the-next-three-years",
      "title": "Wipro Unveils AI360 and Commits $1B in AI Investing",
      "content": "All 250,000 Wipro employees will be trained on AI \n\nEAST BRUNSWICK, N.J. | BENGALURU, India – July 12, 2023: Wipro Limited (NYSE: WIT, BSE: 507685, NSE: WIPRO), a leading technology services and consulting company, today announced the launch of Wipro ai360, a comprehensive, AI-first innovation ecosystem that builds on Wipro’s decade-long investments in artificial intelligence (AI) with the goal of integrating AI into every platform, every tool, and every solution used internally and offered to clients. Along with the launch of Wipro ai360, the company also committed to making a $1 billion investment in advancing AI capabilities over the next three years. [...] Wipro ai360, fueled by this new investment, will help unleash a new era of value, productivity, and commercial opportunities through the application of AI and generative AI.\n\n“Artificial Intelligence is a fast-moving field,” said Thierry Delaporte, Chief Executive Officer and Managing Director, Wipro Limited. “Especially with the emergence of generative AI, we expect a fundamental shift up ahead, for all industries. New business models, new ways of working, and new challenges, too. This is exactly why Wipro’s ai360 ecosystem places responsible AI operations at the heart of all our AI work. It’s meant to empower our talent pool and be ubiquitous across all our operations and processes, as well as our solutioning for clients. We are ready for the AI-driven future!” [...] With responsible AI at its core, Wipro ai360 will bring together the 30,000 Wipro experts in data analytics and AI with Wipro’s technology and advisory ecosystem from four global business lines. Capabilities across cloud and partnerships; data, analytics and AI; design and consulting; cybersecurity; as well as engineering will be leveraged to develop new solutions and embed AI into all processes and practices. Wipro’s new global business line model will enable new levels of agility, speed, and depth in delivery.\n\nFurthermore, Wipro’s innovation hub Lab45 will be a core part of the Wipro ai360 ecosystem, providing clients with the talent, training, scale, as well as the research and co-innovation capabilities needed to accelerate AI adoption.",
      "score": 0.47227025,

      "title": "AI in the workplace: A report for 2025 | McKinsey",
      "content": "The exhibit shows the anticipated timeline for US employees' and business leaders’ use of gen AI for more than 30 percent of their daily work tasks, presented as two stacked bar charts, one for C-suite respondents and one for employees. The segments are broken down into five categories representing different timeframes: Already using, less than a year, 1-5 years, over 5 years, and don't anticipate it. A final category, not sure, is also included. A key finding highlighted in the chart is that employees are three times more likely to be using gen AI today than their leaders expect (4 percent of C-suite respondents estimate that employees are currently using gen AI for more than 30 percent of their daily tasks, while 13 percent of employees self-report they are currently doing so). For the [...] ### Beyond the tipping point\n\nIn our survey, nearly all employees (94 percent) and C-suite leaders (99 percent) report having some level of familiarity with gen AI tools. Nevertheless, business leaders underestimate how extensively their employees are using gen AI. C-suite leaders estimate that only 4 percent of employees use gen AI for at least 30 percent of their daily work, when in fact that percentage is three times greater, as self-reported by employees (Exhibit 2). And while only a total of 20 percent of leaders believe employees will use gen AI for more than 30 percent of their daily tasks within a year, employees are twice as likely (47 percent) to believe they will (see sidebar “Who is using AI at work? Nearly everyone, even skeptical employees”). [...] The top section of the exhibit examines the frequency of inquiries that managers field from their employees about using new gen AI tools at work. This is depicted as a horizontal bar chart showing percentages of respondents. 5 percent of managers report less than quarterly inquiries; 5 percent report quarterly inquiries; 12 percent report inquiries once a month; 15 percent report once a week; 28 percent report a few times a week; 9 percent report once a day; and 16 percent report multiple times a day. Finally, 10 percent of report not at all.",

      "url": "https://www.cognizant.com/us/en/aem-i/ai-and-the-future-of-work-report",
      "title": "New Work, New World 2026: How AI is Reshaping Work",
      "content": "We wanted to quantify the economic value of the total amount of work that AI could assist with or automate today. To do that, we used data from the US Bureau of Labor Statistics on the number of employees in each of the occupation groups in our study and then multiplied that by these employees’ median annual salaries. Then, using our exposure scores, we assessed the amount of this total economic value that could theoretically be exposed to AI.\n\nThe result—$4.5 trillion—is based on the assumption that the traditional way a task is completed would shift seamlessly to AI. Despite being theoretical, however, the calculation provides a glimpse into the sweeping economic change AI could bring. [...] We wanted to quantify the economic value of the total amount of work that AI could assist with or automate today.       "url": "https://www.computerworld.com/video/4115615/what-are-ambient-agents-why-ai-that-acts-will-redefine-automation-at-work.html",
      "title": "What are ambient agents? Why AI that acts will redefine ...",
      "content": "With ambient agents, those questions are handled automatically. HR professionals can focus on higher-value tasks. Keith: Some companies are training employees for more advanced work — level 3 or 4 support — because AI can now take over levels 0 and 1. Bhavin: That’s right.\n\nAmbient agents improve the quality of work and life. Studies show many AI initiatives don’t impact P&L because companies overpromise on automation and underdeliver. The key is augmenting — not replacing — human effort.\n\nShow more Show less\n\n20:00\n\nKeith: Give me a concrete example from IT support. Can you share a real case where an ambient agent caught something before a help desk did? Bhavin: Sure. Let’s say there are 10 VPN disconnects in a region. An ambient agent detects the pattern and alerts IT. [...] It really comes down to whether the company is cloud-forward and already invested in automation. Keith: That makes sense. But I can hear IT folks asking: “Is this just another tool to bolt onto our existing stack?” How easy is integration? Bhavin: Ambient agents are challenging the current model.\n\nCopilots today mostly enhance the platform they live in — like Salesforce or Microsoft. But ambient agents work across systems — Slack, Workday, Jira, ServiceNow. That requires more expansive integration but delivers far more value. Fortunately, platforms are becoming more extensible, which helps. [...] Episode 355 What are ambient agents? In this episode of Today in Tech, host Keith Shaw interviews Bhavin Shah, CEO of Moveworks, about how these proactive agents will transform everything from IT support to HR compliance and software license management.",

      "url": "https://www.workday.com/en-us/perspectives/ai/2026/01/improve-ai-agents-in-new-year.html",
      "title": "The Garage Band Era of AI Agents Is Over",
      "content": "Sydney Scott Editorial Strategist, AI Workday\n\nSydney Scott is an editorial strategist at Workday, developing thought leadership content with a focus on AI and emerging tech trends.  \n   \n Sydney has more than 10 years of experience in content strategy, social media marketing, and journalism. Prior to joining Workday, she developed content strategies for products across Meta and worked as a social strategist and journalist for places like the Tribeca Film Festival, ESSENCE, and BuzzFeed.  \n   \n She holds a bachelor’s degree in communications from Temple University.\n\nMore perspectives from Sydney\n\nThe Business Value of AI [...] Sydney Scott\n\nEditorial Strategist, AI\n\nWorkday\n\nIn this article\n\nJanuary 12, 2026   7 min read\n\n4. Link Copied\n\nRemember the early days of agentic AI? It felt like starting a garage band with your friends. You messed around with fun tools, made some noise, and didn't worry about being perfect. It was exciting, chaotic, and low-stakes.\n\nBut in 2026, the jam sessions are over.\n\nNow it’s time to get practical. The wild excitement around AI is being replaced by a focus on what actually works. The goal has shifted from exploring what AI can do to proving what it should do for your business. We are trading the thrill of jam sessions for the discipline of clear rules and real profits. [...] ## 4. Fix the Feedback Loop (The \"Workslop\" Tax)\n\nLeaders are checking the receipts.\n\nAccording to Forrester, CEOs are expected to pull CFOs into more AI decisions this year, which might actually delay 25% of planned AI spending.\n\nWhy the hesitation? Because of a hidden cost called \"workslop.”\n\nWorkslop is the messy, low-quality output that bad AI creates. It sounds productive—your AI writes a report in seconds!—but then your human employees have to spend hours fixing the errors. Workday thinks of this as the “AI Tax.”\n\nAccording to Workday research, nearly 40% of AI’s promised productivity is silently lost to rework. For every 10 hours of time you save using AI, your team pays back four hours just fixing the output.",

      "content": "PLEASANTON, Calif., Jan. 14, 2026 /PRNewswire/ -- Workday, Inc (NASDAQ: WDAY) today released new global research showing that while AI is delivering productivity gains, many organizations aren't fully capturing its value. Employees are saving meaningful time with AI tools, but too often those gains are being absorbed by rework – fixing mistakes, rewriting content, and double-checking outputs from generic tools – leaving significant value on the table. [...] About WorkdayWorkday is the enterprise AI platform for managing people, money, and agents. Workday unifies HR and Finance on one intelligent platform with AI at the core to empower people at every level with the clarity, confidence, and insights they need to adapt quickly, make better decisions, and deliver outcomes that matter. Workday is used by more than 11,000 organizations around the world and across industries – from medium-sized businesses to more than 65% of the Fortune 500. Our philosophy is that AI should do the complex work under the hood so people can focus on judgment, creativity, and connection. That's how organizations turn AI‑powered speed into durable, human‑led advantage.\"\n\nThe AI Productivity Paradox",

      "url": "https://markets.ft.com/data/announce/detail?dockey=600-202601140530PR_NEWS_USPRX____LA62950-1",
      "title": "Companies Are Leaving AI Gains on the Table - Markets data",
      "content": "About Workday   Workday  is the enterprise AI platform for managing   people  ,   money  , and   agents  . Workday unifies HR and Finance on one intelligent platform with AI at the core to empower people at every level with the clarity, confidence, and insights they need to adapt quickly, make better decisions, and deliver outcomes that matter. Workday is used by more than 11,000 organizations around the world and across industries – from medium-sized businesses to more than 65% of the Fortune 500. For more information about Workday, visit   workday.com  .\n\n© 2026 Workday, Inc. All rights reserved. Workday and the Workday logo are registered trademarks of Workday, Inc. All other trademarks are the property of their respective owners. [...] PLEASANTON, Calif. , Jan. 14, 2026/PRNewswire/ -- Workday, Inc (NASDAQ: WDAY) today released new global research showing that while AI is delivering productivity gains, many organizations aren't fully capturing its value. Employees are saving meaningful time with AI tools, but too often those gains are being absorbed by rework – fixing mistakes, rewriting content, and double-checking outputs from generic tools – leaving significant value on the table. [...] \"Too many AI tools push the hard questions of trust, accuracy, and repeatability back onto individual users,\" said Gerrit Kazmaier, president, product and technology, Workday. \"At Workday, we've spent years delivering AI as simple, human‑centered solutions – not raw technology – so customers aren't left to wire things together and fact‑check every answer on their own. Our philosophy is that AI should do the complex work under the hood so people can focus on judgment, creativity, and connection. That's how organizations turn AI‑powered speed into durable, human‑led advantage.\"\n\nThe AI Productivity Paradox",
      "score": 0.8315952,
      "raw_content": null
    },

      "content": "About WorkdayWorkday is the enterprise AI platform for managing people, money, and agents. Workday unifies HR and Finance on one intelligent platform with AI at the core to empower people at every level with the clarity, confidence, and insights they need to adapt quickly, make better decisions, and deliver outcomes that matter. Workday is used by more than 11,000 organizations around the world and across industries – from medium-sized businesses to more than 65% of the Fortune 500. For more information about Workday, visit workday.com.\n\n© 2026 Workday, Inc. All rights reserved. Workday and the Workday logo are registered trademarks of Workday, Inc. All other trademarks are the property of their respective owners. [...] \"Too many AI tools push the hard questions of trust, accuracy, and repeatability back onto individual users,\" said Gerrit Kazmaier, president, product and technology, Workday. \"At Workday, we've spent years delivering AI as simple, human‑centered solutions – not raw technology – so customers aren't left to wire things together and fact‑check every answer on their own. Our philosophy is that AI should do the complex work under the hood so people can focus on judgment, creativity, and connection. That's how organizations turn AI‑powered speed into durable, human‑led advantage.\"\n\nThe AI Productivity Paradox [...] Workday, Logo\nWorkday, Logo\n\n# Press Release Details\n\n### New Workday Research: Companies Are Leaving AI Gains on the Table\n\nNearly 40% of AI Time Savings Are Lost to Fixing Low-Quality Output\n\nGlobal Research Shows AI Delivers Greater ROI When Leaders Invest in Both People and Technology\n\nPLEASANTON, Calif., Jan. 14, 2026 /PRNewswire/ -- Workday, Inc (NASDAQ: WDAY) today released new global research showing that while AI is delivering productivity gains, many organizations aren't fully capturing its value. Employees are saving meaningful time with AI tools, but too often those gains are being absorbed by rework – fixing mistakes, rewriting content, and double-checking outputs from generic tools – leaving significant value on the table.\n\nWorkday (PRNewsfoto/Workday)\")",

      "url": "https://www.alight.com/blog/mental-health-impact-of-ai",
      "title": "The mental health impact of AI: Navigating anxiety, ...",
      "content": "This trepidation translates into a more negative outlook on work. Employees scared by AI are more likely to dread starting their workday (56% vs. 23% of those not scared by AI). These findings suggest that AI-related anxiety can have far-reaching consequences for worker wellbeing and job satisfaction.\n\n32%\n\nof employees express concern about what AI will mean in the future\n\n28%\n\nof employees feel suspicious about the technology’s output\n\n17%\n\nof employees feel genuinely curious about the potential of AI [...] As AI continues to reshape the workplace, employees’ attitudes reflect a mix of optimism and apprehension about its potential impact on their careers. Aware that artificial intelligence isn’t going away, they have accepted that AI will be increasingly interwoven into everything they do — at work and at home. Try as they might to despise this inevitable encroachment, many people are feeling a sense of excitement about exploring the technology and discovering what it can do.\n\nAI apprehension crosses generations [...] The root of the fear: job securityAs an increasing number of workers find themselves expected to use AI in their daily work,  job loss anxiety has emerged as a critical emotional driver. While 39% of employees admit that AI scares them, it’s clear they aren't afraid of the technology itself, but rather what it might mean for their professional futures. One-third of Mindset respondents say they fear AI will take away their job, while nearly half (45%) are concerned they will fall behind if they don’t learn how to use it. Yet while workers feel a sense of urgency for learning AI, 44% believe it has a long way to go before it can be useful.",
      "score": 0.5900477,

    {
      "url": "https://boomi.com/resources/resources-library/mcp-isnt-the-answer-its-the-question/",
      "title": "MCP Isn't the Answer, It's the Question",
      "content": "Still, there is a long way to go. Although the MCP authorization protocol is now well-defined, the complexity of seemingly simplistic agentic workflows can exceed what the spec currently provides. For example, imagine an AI agent whose purpose is to help Human Resources workers with employee onboarding. That agent might need tools to add employee contact information in Workday, add payroll details in ADP, and open tickets in ServiceNow to issue new IT equipment. This use case alone would need to consider the identity of the HR worker, the scope of the agent, and the permission level required to access each back end application. Given the dynamic nature of agentic processing, ensuring appropriate access control is even more critical than in more deterministic settings. [...] Engineers should rely on AI to automate tedious tasks like healing broken tests automatically and generating boilerplate test cases. But humans should remain in charge of which tests are executed and how to react to complex test failures.\n\nRohit Raghuvansi \n\nJan 13, 2026\n\nArtificial intelligence technologies\n\n Real-time Analytics News for the Week Ending January 10 \n\nIn this week’s real-time analytics news: NVIDIA launched its new NVIDIA Rubin platform that accelerates AI workloads.\n\nSalvatore Salamone \n\nJan 10, 2026\n\nArtificial intelligence technologies\n\n Model-as-a-Service Part 1: The Basics [...] Featured Resources\n\n  Link to Best Practices for Deploying and Scaling Industrial AI \n\n  Best Practices for Deploying and Scaling Industrial AI\n\n  Artificial Intelligence (AI) is transforming industrial operations, helping organizations optimize workflows, reduce downtime, and enhance productivity. However, a multimodal reasoning agent today could notice a damp patch on a wall, infer a leaking joint, draft a repair plan and even generate an invoice or parts list. The plumber still fixes the pipe, but the inspection, diagnosis and supportive actions that lead up to or follow it can increasingly be assisted by AI.  \n   \n Reasoning and perception are beginning to overlap in almost any role that needs situational judgment. Retail store planning, vehicle servicing and energy infrastructure maintenance all rely on visual understanding and procedural thinking. The compounding effect helps the coordination, diagnosis and verification that connects thought with action.",

      "url": "https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/viva/import-org-data-workday",
      "title": "Import organizational data from Workday (preview)",
      "content": "1. Start the import from the Select connection type page on the Organizational Data in Microsoft 365 page (Home > Setup > Migration and imports > Organizational Data in Microsoft 365 > Select connection type). Under Workday connector, select Start Workday setup.\n2. Select Get started (if this is the first time you're importing data), or New import (if you've already imported data).\n3. On the Select connection type page, select Start Workday setup.\n4. Under Download your Workday certificate, select Download certificate. A x509 certificate file will download called \"publicKey.pem.\" Open the file in a text editor and copy its contents. Share this with the Workday admin.\n5. Read the acknowledgment note and select Next.\n6. Under Set up Workday connection: [...] | Attribute | Workday field |\n --- |\n| Microsoft\\_PersonEmail | /wd:Worker/wd:Worker\\_Data/wd:Personal\\_Data/wd:Contact\\_Data/wd:Email\\_Address\\_Data/wd:Email\\_Address |\n| Microsoft\\_ManagerEmail | /wd:Worker/wd:Worker\\_Data/wd:Employment\\_Data/wd:Worker\\_Job\\_Data/wd:Position\\_Data/wd:Manager\\_as\\_of\\_last\\_detected\\_manager\\_change\\_Reference/wd:ID[@wd:type=\"Employee\\_ID\" or @wd:type=\\\"Contingent\\_Worker\\_ID\"] |\n| Microsoft\\_Organization (Department) | /wd:Worker/wd:Worker\\_Data/wd:Organization\\_Data/wd:Worker\\_Organization\\_Data/wd:Organization\\_Data/wd:Organization\\_Name |\n| Microsoft\\_Layer | No mapping from Workday | [...] ## Feedback\n\nWas this page helpful?\n\nNo \n\nNeed help with this topic?\n\nWant to try using Ask Learn to clarify or guide you through this topic?\n\n## Additional resources\n\n Last updated on  2025-09-02",

    {
      "url": "https://www.mercer.com/en-us/insights/us-health-news/unlocking-the-power-of-benefits-data-and-ai/",
      "title": "Unlocking the power of benefits data and AI",
      "content": "Furthermore, automating routine tasks through AI — such as eligibility verification, claims processing, and reporting — reduces administrative burdens and minimizes errors. This not only improves efficiency but also frees HR teams to focus on strategic initiatives like employee engagement and benefits design.\n\nPredicting employee behavior and needs\n\nOne of AI’s most powerful applications is its ability to forecast employee needs. The employee benefits lifecycle is not a new concept but understanding it remains crucial. Employees’ needs evolve over time, from first job benefits to retirement planning. For example, younger employees may focus on student debt and early career development, while those in their 50s and 60s are more concerned with healthcare and retirement options. [...] Ensure data readiness: Build a solid foundation with accurate, comprehensive data on employee demographics, eligibility, job functions, and pay. High-quality data is essential for reliable AI insights.\n Enhance efficiency: Automation and AI solutions to streamline administration and improve the employee experience. For example, the administration system can “learn” from how an employee has answered decision-support questions and prefill responses when they going back into the system to review or make changes.\n Understand what you’re paying for: Leverage data science to analyze your benefits spend and utilization. This helps optimize costs while ensuring employees receive meaningful support. [...] Enrollment patterns, claims data, utilization rates and demographic details provide a comprehensive picture of employee preferences and behaviors. When analyzed effectively,  this data can inform strategic decisions that enhance employee experience and operational efficiency and point the way to cost savings. For example, if data indicates a rising interest in mental health resources, employers can expand relevant offerings, demonstrating responsiveness and care. Similarly, AI can reveal which benefits are underutilized and not providing value, helping employers optimize investments by negotiating better rates, eliminating redundant coverage, or streamlining plan options",

      "url": "https://vendordirectory.shrm.org/company/937808/news/3747252/data-driven-compensation-planning-tool-how-hr-teams-can-move-beyond-spreadsheets",
      "title": "Data-Driven Compensation Planning Tool: How HR Teams ...",
      "content": "Turnkey integrations with major HRIS and payroll systems—including Workday, UKG, ADP, SAP SuccessFactors, Oracle, BambooHR, and Rippling—enable automated data flows rather than manual uploads each cycle.\n Single sign-on support through common identity providers like Okta and Azure AD ensures seamless access while maintaining security standards.\n The ability to import existing survey data from providers like Mercer, Radford, ERI, and Culpepper protects previous investments while enabling gradual transition to real-time datasets. [...] Market Pricing Capabilities\n\nMarket pricing capabilities should enable HR teams to quickly benchmark any role against current U.S. market conditions.  Users select specific job titles, experience levels, and geographic locations—whether San Francisco Bay Area, Denver metro, Atlanta region, or fully remote U.S.—and retrieve current percentile data for base salary, total cash compensation, and equity packages. AI-assisted job matching helps align internal position titles with external benchmarks, particularly valuable for hybrid roles like “DevOps Engineer with AI/ML focus” or “Revenue Operations Analyst” that span traditional job family boundaries. [...] Modern real-time datasets offer granular segmentation by detailed job titles, job families, experience levels, and U.S. metropolitan areas or broader regional clusters. Advanced platforms like SalaryCube’s Bigfoot Live provide daily-updated benchmarks with transparent methodology documentation and sample size disclosure, ensuring HR teams can evaluate data quality and make defendable decisions. The ability to price hybrid or emerging roles through AI-assisted job matching addresses the growing challenge of compensation benchmarking for positions that don’t fit traditional survey categories.\n\nInternal HRIS and Payroll Data\n\nInternal HRIS and payroll data must flow automatically into planning workflows rather than requiring manual uploads each cycle.       "content": "About WorkdayWorkday is the enterprise AI platform for managing people, money, and agents. Workday unifies HR and Finance on one intelligent platform with AI at the core to empower people at every level with the clarity, confidence, and insights they need to adapt quickly, make better decisions, and deliver outcomes that matter. Workday is used by more than 11,000 organizations around the world and across industries – from medium-sized businesses to more than 65% of the Fortune 500. For more information about Workday, visit workday.com.\n\n© 2026 Workday, Inc. All rights reserved. Workday and the Workday logo are registered trademarks of Workday, Inc. All other trademarks are the property of their respective owners. [...] PLEASANTON, Calif., Jan. 14, 2026 /PRNewswire/ -- Workday, Inc (NASDAQ: WDAY) today released new global research showing that while AI is delivering productivity gains, many organizations aren't fully capturing its value. Employees are saving meaningful time with AI tools, but too often those gains are being absorbed by rework – fixing mistakes, rewriting content, and double-checking outputs from generic tools – leaving significant value on the table. [...] \"Too many AI tools push the hard questions of trust, accuracy, and repeatability back onto individual users,\" said Gerrit Kazmaier, president, product and technology, Workday. \"At Workday, we've spent years delivering AI as simple, human‑centered solutions – not raw technology – so customers aren't left to wire things together and fact‑check every answer on their own. Our philosophy is that AI should do the complex work under the hood so people can focus on judgment, creativity, and connection. That's how organizations turn AI‑powered speed into durable, human‑led advantage.\"\n\nThe AI Productivity Paradox",

    {
      "url": "https://boomi.com/resources/resources-library/mcp-isnt-the-answer-its-the-question/",
      "title": "MCP Isn't the Answer, It's the Question",
      "content": "Still, there is a long way to go. Although the MCP authorization protocol is now well-defined, the complexity of seemingly simplistic agentic workflows can exceed what the spec currently provides. For example, imagine an AI agent whose purpose is to help Human Resources workers with employee onboarding. That agent might need tools to add employee contact information in Workday, add payroll details in ADP, and open tickets in ServiceNow to issue new IT equipment. This use case alone would need to consider the identity of the HR worker, the scope of the agent, and the permission level required to access each back end application. Given the dynamic nature of agentic processing, ensuring appropriate access control is even more critical than in more deterministic settings. [...] Engineers should rely on AI to automate tedious tasks like healing broken tests automatically and generating boilerplate test cases. But humans should remain in charge of which tests are executed and how to react to complex test failures.\n\nRohit Raghuvansi \n\nJan 13, 2026\n\nArtificial intelligence technologies\n\n Real-time Analytics News for the Week Ending January 10 \n\nIn this week’s real-time analytics news: NVIDIA launched its new NVIDIA Rubin platform that accelerates AI workloads.\n\nSalvatore Salamone \n\nJan 10, 2026\n\nArtificial intelligence technologies\n\n Model-as-a-Service Part 1: The Basics [...] Featured Resources\n\n  Link to Best Practices for Deploying and Scaling Industrial AI \n\n  Best Practices for Deploying and Scaling Industrial AI\n\n  Artificial Intelligence (AI) is transforming industrial operations, helping organizations optimize workflows, reduce downtime, and enhance productivity.       "url": "https://www.deloitte.com/us/en/services/consulting/articles/how-to-navigate-economics-of-ai.html",
      "title": "Navigate the Economics Of AI",
      "content": "Packaged AI solutions (e.g., Agentforce, ServiceNow Copilot, Workday AI) abstract tokens entirely. Leaders see a predictable subscription or per-seat fee, but little transparency into token consumption efficiency. The risk is overpaying for simplicity.\n API and model consumption (e.g., Anthropic, OpenAI, Together AI) make tokens explicit. Every query is metered, billed and exposed. This brings transparency, but also volatility: costs rise based on workload design, prompt length, and hidden choices of infrastructure providers. AI costs go up due to a token meter running in real time. [...] How can businesses adapt to surging AI workloads? Read our analysis on the growth of AI computing infrastructure and strategies to meet evolving demands.\n\nArticle\n\n### Deloitte Cloud Services\n\nCloud consulting services designed to deliver purpose-driven transformation for strategic advantage.\n\nService",

However, a multimodal reasoning agent today could notice a damp patch on a wall, infer a leaking joint, draft a repair plan and even generate an invoice or parts list. The plumber still fixes the pipe, but the inspection, diagnosis and supportive actions that lead up to or follow it can increasingly be assisted by AI.  \n   \n Reasoning and perception are beginning to overlap in almost any role that needs situational judgment. Retail store planning, vehicle servicing and energy infrastructure maintenance all rely on visual understanding and procedural thinking.     {
      "url": "https://www.zdnet.com/article/stop-cleaning-up-after-ai-keep-productivity-gains/",
      "title": "6 ways to stop cleaning up after AI",
      "content": "That's the lesson being learned among employees and executives responding to a new survey by Workday. While AI is delivering productivity gains, those gains are being partially washed away when technologists or employees need to go back to implementations to fix mistakes, rewrite content, or double-check outputs. At least 37% of time savings gained through AI are lost to fixing low-quality output, according to the survey's authors, which included the experiences of 3,200 practitioners.\n\n## The ultimate AI productivity paradox [...] It's the ultimate AI productivity paradox, the Workday authors argue. The speed gained through AI's time savings \"doesn't always translate into better outcomes.\" At least 85% of employees report saving one to seven hours per week using AI. However, the follow-up rework required washes out the savings -- to the tune of an average 1.5 weeks a year spent fixing AI outputs, the survey analysts estimate. Only 14% of employees consistently achieve net-positive outcomes from AI use, they add.\n\nAlso:Your colleagues are sick of your AI workslop [...] Also:Worried AI will take your remote job? You're safe for now, this study shows\n\nThe organizations realizing the greatest value from AI \"treat saved time as a strategic resource,\" the Workday team states. \"They reinvest in upskilling their teams, improving collaboration, and strengthening judgment-driven work. The biggest opportunity is helping employees learn how to use AI effectively -- especially in areas that require judgment, creativity, and decision-making.\"\n\n#### Artificial Intelligence\n\nI tried Gemini's 'scheduled actions' to automate my AI - the potential is enormous (but Google has work to do)\")\n\nHow to remove Copilot AI from Windows 11 today\n\nIs AI coming for your job? Here's one labor indicator that could soothe your fears",

    {
      "url": "https://www.zdnet.com/article/ai-could-eliminate-boredom-value-busy-work/",
      "title": "Is AI's war on busywork a creativity killer? What the experts ...",
      "content": "\"There's a risk in assuming that every recovered minute should be filled with more high-intensity work,\" she said. \"If teams are constantly pushed from one cognitively demanding task to the next, creativity and strategic clarity actually suffer … AI should not turn the workday into a nonstop sprint, [but] rather create a better rhythm.\"\n\nAn overreliance on AI tools in the workplace also raises the risk of creating a fractured, lonely workplace. [...] ## 'AI should not turn the workday into a nonstop sprint'\n\nAnother central problem with the AI industry's sales pitch is that even the most productive, disciplined workers can't sustain intensely focused work indefinitely. We all have creative peaks and valleys over the course of a day; the trick is for each of us to get to know our own particular cognitive rhythms and learn to work with them.\n\nTo believe that we can simply offload busywork onto AI and perpetually focus on more cognitively demanding work is to misunderstand our own minds. [...] \"I suspect that if we optimized entirely for highly cognitive work, we'd run into diminishing returns on quality,\" said Shawn Spooner, global chief technology officer at advertising agency Billups. \"A better paradigm would be to aim to keep our folks in flow state for a few multi-hour blocks each day, where they are the most productive and the most happy, stitched together with more mundane tasks to give their day a more natural ebb and flow.\"\n\nAlso: 3 ways anyone can start using AI at work today - safely\n\nDebra Andrews, president of consulting firm Marketri, echoed that idea that the optimal workday is one that harmonizes hyper-focused productivity with relaxed downtime.",

      "url": "https://www.alight.com/blog/mental-health-impact-of-ai",
      "title": "The mental health impact of AI: Navigating anxiety, ...",
      "content": "This trepidation translates into a more negative outlook on work. Employees scared by AI are more likely to dread starting their workday (56% vs. 23% of those not scared by AI). These findings suggest that AI-related anxiety can have far-reaching consequences for worker wellbeing and job satisfaction.\n\n32%\n\nof employees express concern about what AI will mean in the future\n\n28%\n\nof employees feel suspicious about the technology’s output\n\n17%\n\nof employees feel genuinely curious about the potential of AI [...] The 2025 Alight Employee Mindset Study reveals a complex narrative of cautious engagement rather than outright rejection. Nearly two in five U.S. workers are experiencing significant anxiety about artificial intelligence. However, contrary to popular belief, AI-anxious workers aren't technological luddites — nor are they aging Boomers or elder Gen Xers, often portrayed as being leery of new technology after watching a lifetime of the “latest and greatest” innovations come and go. Rather, these are nuanced professionals of all ages wrestling with a transformative force that promises both opportunity and potential displacement. Spoiler alert: Younger workers are actually more likely to express AI-related fears than their more seasoned colleagues — with Gen Z emerging as the most [...] As AI continues to reshape the workplace, employees’ attitudes reflect a mix of optimism and apprehension about its potential impact on their careers. Aware that artificial intelligence isn’t going away, they have accepted that AI will be increasingly interwoven into everything they do — at work and at home. Try as they might to despise this inevitable encroachment, many people are feeling a sense of excitement about exploring the technology and discovering what it can do.\n\nAI apprehension crosses generations",

      "title": "The Forrester Wave™: Intranet Platforms, Q2 2024 Is Now Live!",
      "content": "Home > Featured Blogs > The Forrester Wave™: Intranet Platforms, Q2 2024 Is Now Live! # The Forrester Wave™: Intranet Platforms, Q2 2024 Is Now Live! The Forrester Wave™: Intranet Platforms, Q2 2024 published on June 6. Automation, AI (particularly generative AI), and data-driven analytics have been major areas of investments for many of the vendors in this evaluation. Here are key findings from this Forrester Wave:. * **Generative AI is shaping vendors’ roadmaps, but adoption by users is in early days.** Writing assistants, automated translations, content transformations, and intelligent agents/bots have all entered the intranet and employee communications landscape. Common examples include end-to-end content and communication delivery flows, such as for new hire onboarding (i.e., automatically deliver tasks and educational information over a new worker’s first 90 days), and multistep campaigns and calendars to help coordinate streams of communication, including reports and/or AI to help optimize delivery times, days, or channels. * **Reporting and dashboards show big improvements.** Vendors have made important investments here with an eye to giving intranet program leaders and communication pros the data to truly understand how users engage with content. Digital workplace leaders looking to build a shortlist and estimate a budget will need to do more upfront research to understand their requirements and know their workforce (e.g., number of desk workers vs. I’ll be hosting a webinar for Forrester clients about The Forrester Wave: Intranet Platforms, Q2 2024 on July 16 at 11:00 a.m. ET. And, as always, I’d love to talk more about your intranet, employee communications, and digital workplace needs. ###### Related Forrester Content. * The Forrester Wave: Intranet Platforms Q2 2024. #### Forrester’s B2B Summits connect you with analysts and insights to help you navigate buying shifts, win with AI, accelerate growth, and transform revenue. At Tanium Converge 2025 in Orlando, Florida, Tanium CEO Dan Streetman kicked things off by highlighting Tanium’s strategy shift — extending beyond managing and securing endpoints to delivering autonomous IT platform solutions. For years, organizations have poured money into collaboration tools, intranets, devices, workflow platforms, and automation — all under the banner of “improving the digital employee experience.” Yet employee frustration with digital friction remains.",

    {
      "url": "https://www.forrester.com/blogs/key-takeaways-from-the-forrester-wave-dma-platforms-q2-2025",
      "title": "Key Takeaways From The Forrester Wave™: Data Management For Analytics Platforms, Q2 2025",
      "content": "Key Takeaways From The Forrester Wave™: Data Management For Analytics Platforms, Q2 2025. # Key Takeaways From The Forrester Wave™: Data Management For Analytics Platforms, Q2 2025. I’m excited to announce the release of **The Forrester Wave™: Data Management For Analytics Platforms, Q2 2025**. This edition evaluated the 11 most significant data management and analytics (DMA) platform vendors, providing a comprehensive view of a market undergoing rapid transformation. Over the past decade, we’ve consistently published the DMA Wave, tracking the evolution of the space and offering guidance to enterprises navigating their data strategy, but this year’s evaluation reflects a notable shift. This year’s Wave captures how vendors are adapting with new and advanced capabilities fueled by advanced automation, integrated data intelligence, and AI-driven data management. Generative AI is emerging as a transformative force, enhancing both automation and intelligence within DMA. As a result, selecting the right DMA platform provider to support immediate and long-term data strategies has become increasingly complex. * **Generative AI is automating DMA functions.** The modern DMA platform is automating complex tasks such as data ingestion, cleansing, transformation, integration, governance, and security. Natural language allows users to interact with data, generate insights, and manage platforms without deep technical expertise. Leading vendors leverage agentic AI and natural language capabilities to deliver more intelligent and integrated data management. * **Built-in data intelligence is elevating DMA to a new level.** Built-in data intelligence is streamlining data semantic-related tasks, dramatically improving efficiency and unlocking deeper insights. With generative AI and data intelligence becoming foundational to modern DMA platforms, vendors increasingly embed these capabilities — although vendor offerings range from basic to highly advanced, integrated solutions. This holistic approach ensures that our evaluation reflects the rising demand for intelligent, intuitive, and highly automated data management solutions. If your organization still relies on traditional data management tools for analytical workloads, now is the time to shift to a modern DMA platform. Modern platforms powered by genAI, advanced automation, and intelligence enable the real-time delivery of consistent and trusted data. Upgrading your DMA platform isn’t just a technology upgrade; it’s a strategic move toward becoming a data-driven, AI-enabled organization.",
      "score": 0.6929958,
      "raw_content": null

Watch Forrester’s Take On 2026 Scenario Planning [...] Context matters when trying to get value out of genAI. Bring AI to your content rather than bringing your content to AI. Using the embedded genAI capabilities from your content platform vendor can provide an unfair advantage. Most evaluated vendors are using a retrieval-augmented generation architecture that shields your corporate content from public AI models, and also respects existing access controls and permission structures. Exposing a genAI assistant in a folder, a workspace, or search result interface can ground the AI in the that specific context — i.e., a customer case, a project folder, or list of incoming claims — to return specific answers and relevant citation links to source documents.",

      "url": "https://www.forrester.com/blogs/key-takeaways-from-the-forrester-wave-business-intelligence-platforms-q2-2025-research/",
      "title": "Key Takeaways From The Forrester Wave™: Business Intelligence Platforms, Q2 2025",
      "content": "Home > Featured Blogs > Key Takeaways From The Forrester Wave™: Business Intelligence Platforms, Q2 2025. # Key Takeaways From The Forrester Wave™: Business Intelligence Platforms, Q2 2025. Forrester recently published our latest evaluation of business intelligence (BI) platform offerings: The Forrester Wave™: Business Intelligence Platforms, Q2 2025. 2. **GenAI is not the end of BI.** Generative AI (genAI) is not replacing business intelligence; instead, it’s leveling the playing field as all BI vendors integrate generative and agentic AI capabilities based on the same large language models (LLMs). Every BI vendor is now making a claim that their platform is genAI- and agentic AI-based. But *how* BI vendors are leveraging the power of genAI is what makes the difference. This means that data, analytics, and AI leaders must be very clear on how each BI vendor is delivering genAI-based functionality embedded in the BI platform. * **GenAI functionality.** What specific BI platform functionality is based on genAI (natural language query [NLQ], natural language generation [NLG], enriching semantic layer, etc.)? Does the platform offer any non-core BI, genAI-based functionality such as mining unstructured data, documenting data sets/populating a data catalog, or others? * **GenAI architecture.** What specific foundation LLM APIs and/or BI vendor proprietary language models are provided out of the box? * **GenAI domain specialization.** Does the platform come with industry-/business domain-specific language models? * **GenAI for enterprise data.** How does the platform’s genAI functionality get access to enterprise data, metadata, and other contexts? * **GenAI guardrails.** What are the guardrails the platform uses to ensure that users only have access to LLM results they are allowed to see? For the detailed results, including all eight genAI criteria, 19 other criteria around vendors’ current offerings, and six vendor strategy criteria, please read The Forrester Wave™: Business Intelligence Platforms, Q2 2025, and/or set up a call with me. The choice of agentic AI technology for enterprise leaders is best understood as an ecosystem of tech vendors that align with three functional planes, based on the need to: 1) build agents; 2) embed them into business workflows; and 3) manage and govern them at scale.",
