      "url": "https://www.forrester.com/blogs/announcing-the-forrester-wave-governance-risk-and-compliance-platforms-q4-2023/",
      "title": "Forrester Wave: Governance, Risk, And Compliance Platforms 2023",
      "content": "Home > Featured Blogs > Announcing The Forrester Wave™: Governance, Risk, And Compliance Platforms, Q4 2023. # Announcing The Forrester Wave™: Governance, Risk, And Compliance Platforms, Q4 2023. The Forrester Wave™: Governance, Risk, And Compliance Platforms, Q4 2023, is now live! When Odysseus left Ithaca and sailed to fight in the Trojan War, he had no idea how the gods would impact his journey — or that it would take him over 20 years to return home. Governance, risk, and compliance (GRC) has endured its own 20-year odyssey (but with much less hubris and divine anger). Over time, regulators, companies, and investors learned better practices and began expanding GRC principles broadly across business disciplines — with plenty of setbacks and confusion along the way. Now, with innovations in AI, risk intelligence data, and advanced GRC platform capabilities, the vision of holistic GRC is becoming more attainable and practical for firms of all sizes. Since our last Forrester Wave™ evaluation, three key trends have emerged in the GRC odyssey:. 1. **De-risking risk management.** Changes to workflow, visualizations, and GRC analyst experience improve how platforms reduce friction and scale. 2. **Reimagining GRC processes with artificial intelligence.** The GRC market has talked about machine learning and AI for over a decade, but it was relegated to workflow automations and data integrations. With generative AI’s rise, GRC platforms are rapidly embracing AI for content creation, behavior/event prediction, and knowledge articulation across GRC use cases. We are only at the beginning of seeing how AI will reimagine GRC. 3. **Demonstrating a holistic approach to GRC.** Companies can’t afford to implicitly govern their business and need an effective platform that works with their technology stacks to communicate vertically and horizontally within an enterprise. Leading vendors are showcasing clear views of platform technical depth and breadth that address GRC as a complete program rather than a discrete technology. Whether you are already using a GRC platform or embarking on your first experience, read this report for more insight on the GRC market and the 15 vendors that matter most. * GRC - Governance, Risk, And Compliance. These are all classified as having a primary business impact and include developing and executing data-based campaigns, conducting synthetic customer research, conducting real-time supply chain monitoring, and accelerating coding processes. These use cases fall in the middle of the spectrum between more localized and more universal impact levels. [...] These AI-specific headwinds are formidable but addressable. Stock Movers: Autodesk, Workday, Dell. Listen for comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the US market close as heard on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Katie Greifeld, Tim Stenovec and Carol Massar. On this episode of Stock Movers: - Autodesk (ADSK) gained 5% afterhours after reporting results The company boosted its adjusted earnings per share guidance for the full year; the guidance beat the average analyst estimate. - Workday (WDAY) is up about 3% in afterhours trading. Workday reported adjusted earnings per share for the third quarter of $2.32 vs. The company boosted its subscription revenue forecast for the full year. - Dell Technologies (DELL) raised its annual projections for the AI server market due to sustained demand for machines needed in the current data center boom. The company booked $12.3 billion of AI server orders in the fiscal third quarter and raised shipment projections for the year to $25 billion from $20 billion. Dell's operating margin in its infrastructure unit was 12.4% in the period, and the company's shares rose about 2% in extended trading after the results were announced. ###### Share This Episode:. * %20gained%205%25%20afterhours%20after%20reporting%20results%20The%20company%20boosted%20its%20adjusted%20earnings%20per%20share%20guidance%20for%20the%20full%20year%3B%20the%20guidance%20beat%20the%20average%20analyst%20estimate.%0A%0A-%20Workday%20(WDAY)%20is%20up%20about%203%25%20in%20afterhours%20trading.%20Workday%20reported%20adjusted%20earnings%20per%20share%20for%20the%20third%20quarter%20of%20%242.32%20vs.%20%241.89%20y%2Fy.%20The%20company%20boosted%20its%20subscription%20revenue%20forecast%20for%20the%20full%20year.%0A%0A-%20Dell%20Technologies%20(DELL)%20raised%20its%20annual%20projections%20for%20the%20AI%20server%20market%20due%20to%20sustained%20demand%20for%20machines%20needed%20in%20the%20current%20data%20center%20boom.%20The%20company%20booked%20%2412.3%20billion%20of%20AI%20server%20orders%20in%20the%20fiscal%20third%20quarter%20and%20raised%20shipment%20projections%20for%20the%20year%20to%20%2425%20billion%20from%20%2420%20billion.%20Dell%27s%20operating%20margin%20in%20its%20infrastructure%20unit%20was%2012.4%25%20in%20the%20period%2C%20and%20the%20company%27s%20shares%20rose%20about%202%25%20in%20extended%20trading%20after%20the%20results%20were%20announced.). * %20gained%205%25%20afterhours%20after%20reporting%20results%20The%20company%20boosted%20its%20adjusted%20earnings%20per%20share%20guidance%20for%20the%20full%20year%3B%20the%20guidance%20beat%20the%20average%20analyst%20estimate.%0A%0A-%20Workday%20(WDAY)%20is%20up%20about%203%25%20in%20afterhours%20trading.%20Workday%20reported%20adjusted%20earnings%20per%20share%20for%20the%20third%20quarter%20of%20%242.32%20vs.%20%241.89%20y%2Fy.%20The%20company%20boost...",

Stock Movers • Browse all episodes. ## Stock Movers: Nvidia, BJ's, Workday. ## Stock Movers. ## Nvidia, BJ's, Workday. On this episode of Stock Movers:. - Nvidia (NVDA) shares are after The Information reported, citing unidentified sources, that the company has instructed component suppliers to stop production related to the H20 AI chip. The production suspension comes after Beijing urged local companies to avoid using the H20, a chip designed specifically for the Chinese market. CEO Jensen Huang said he was surprised by Beijing's concerns and reiterated that the H20 houses no security backdoors, according to Huang. - BJ's Wholesale (BJ) fell after it reported fiscal second-quarter sales that came up short of expectations. The profit outlook for the wholesale retailer did improve. It boosted its adjusted earnings per share forecast for the full year. - Ross Stores (ROST) jumped after projecting inflation will push more consumers to seek its off-price wares and deliver sales growth above expectations. CEO Jim Conroy said, “We anticipate pricing across retail will move higher as we progress through the year, which will lead consumers to seek more value this fall season.”. - Workday (WDAY) shares are lower after investors were left disappointed that the human-resources software company left its subscription revenue guidance unchanged, apart from a small boost from the Paradox acquisition. Analysts also flagged concerns around AI displacement continue to linger.",

Analysts also flagged concerns around AI displacement continue to linger. - Zoom (ZM) share are higher after it gave a stronger-than-expected annual outlook for sales growth and raised its fiscal-year forecast, suggesting customers are buying more of the company’s expanded line of software products. Copilots use generative AI and other technologies to understand user requests, perform actions, and provide insights based on business data. Compared to earlier digital assistants, AI copilots provide a more human-like conversational experience and a broader and more flexible range of capabilities.       "title": "What are ambient agents? Why AI that acts will redefine ...",
      "content": "It really comes down to whether the company is cloud-forward and already invested in automation. Keith: That makes sense. But I can hear IT folks asking: “Is this just another tool to bolt onto our existing stack?” How easy is integration? Bhavin: Ambient agents are challenging the current model.\n\nCopilots today mostly enhance the platform they live in — like Salesforce or Microsoft. But ambient agents work across systems — Slack, Workday, Jira, ServiceNow. That requires more expansive integration but delivers far more value. Fortunately, platforms are becoming more extensible, which helps. [...] Learn how ambient agents differ from traditional chatbots and co-pilots, how they deliver real ROI through automation and cost savings, and why enterprises need to rethink privacy, trust and system architecture.       "title": "Joule Copilot from SAP | Artificial Intelligence",
      "content": "Read the blog post\n\n## Frequently asked questions\n\n:   An AI copilot is a virtual assistant that uses a conversational interface to help users of business applications complete tasks more efficiently. Copilots use generative AI and other technologies to understand user requests, perform actions, and provide insights based on business data. Compared to earlier digital assistants, AI copilots provide a more human-like conversational experience and a broader and more flexible range of capabilities. [...] ### Human resources\n\nCreate better employee experiences and boost productivity with AI assistance that helps complete HR tasks up to 90% faster.\\ Find, hire, and retain the best talent with AI agents that streamline hiring and people management activities.\n\nExplore AI for human resources\n\n### Customer experience\n\nDrive revenue and customer satisfaction with AI agents that resolve service requests, boost sales productivity, and increase e-commerce conversions.       "title": "Podcast Making Work 'Work'",
      "content": "Jared Cameron, Principal Digital HR and Technology, Mercer New Zealand, said that in just 12 months, generative AI has become part of everyday work for many organisations and highlighted that the use cases for AI in HR go well beyond efficiency gains from writing job descriptions. But to leverage AI companies will need a strong foundation with data on talent skills, careers and job architecture.\n 44:49 - The audience makes their bet\n 50:40 - Questions from the audience\n\n### \n\nResources [...] Opportunities and challenges for HR in the age on generative AI: Nearly 75% of surveyed companies by the World Economic Forum are expected to adopt generative AI. Mercer's global Talent Trend study also highlights that executives' top priorities include redesigning work for agility which will require them to re-design their HR function.\n Human-centric approach: David emphasises the importance of being \"digital\" rather than just \"doing digital.\" HR should focus on understanding the needs of employees and aligning technology to enhance their experience and productivity. [...] ### \n\n “You can't just do digital, you can't just have technology be an adjunct to what we do, we shouldn't throw it over the fence to our IT folks, we should really own it and understand how we can use the technology to drive and help us be a great strategic function that HR could and should be.”\n\n  - David Guazzarotto, Leader for Digital HR and Technology Advisory practice, Mercer Pacific\n \"80% of projects in the HR Tech space fail. We need to get better at that. And the only way we're going to do that is to stop pushing the technology at everything. I think the opportunity for us and what I like personally working with clients is to help them really understand what is their strategic agenda?\"",

      "title": "PwC deploys Microsoft Copilot at enterprise scale",
      "content": "During the month of October 2025, PwC employees executed over 8.7 million actions in Copilot, freeing up over 500,000 hours of capacity in the process. With 54% of PwC’s global workforce using AI tools weekly, employees average nine prompts per week.\n\nThe impact extends beyond productivity. AI agents now help research teams extract data from complex files in seconds, freeing PwC employees to focus on higher-value insights. Citizen developers are creating low-code applications that further automate and improve processes.\n\nRole-based training helps employees understand how to use agents effectively, spot AI hallucinations, and apply Responsible AI principles in their daily work. Regular playbooks, live demos, and “prompt-of-the-day” campaigns continue to drive engagement. [...] Microsoft’s enterprise-grade architecture has been central to success—offering strong encryption, secure data storage, and region-specific compliance controls. Local data stays local, enabling confidence across our territories.\n\nToday, Copilot isn’t just an assistant. It’s an integrated AI framework that powers smarter, faster, and more trusted work—for PwC and for our clients.\n\nGet more on this topic\n\nEbook: Elevate your AI transformation with PwC and Microsoft Copilot for Microsoft 365\n\nPwC and Microsoft deliver award-winning transformation\n\n“It’s important we have conviction that the technology works in order to build industrial strength solutions with it.     {
      "url": "https://www.deloitte.com/us/en/services/consulting/articles/how-to-navigate-economics-of-ai.html",
      "title": "Navigate the Economics Of AI",
      "content": "Packaged AI solutions (e.g., Agentforce, ServiceNow Copilot, Workday AI) abstract tokens entirely. Leaders see a predictable subscription or per-seat fee, but little transparency into token consumption efficiency. The risk is overpaying for simplicity.\n API and model consumption (e.g., Anthropic, OpenAI, Together AI) make tokens explicit. Every query is metered, billed and exposed. This brings transparency, but also volatility: costs rise based on workload design, prompt length, and hidden choices of infrastructure providers. AI costs go up due to a token meter running in real time. [...] Contributor: Jason Chmiel\n\nDid you find this useful?\n\nYes;)\n\nNo;)\n\n#### Thanks for your feedback\n\n#### Your feedback is important to us\n\nTo tell us what you think, please update your settings to accept analytics and performance cookies.\n\nUpdate analytics and performance\n\nNeed help updating cookies?\n\n### Get in touch with the author team\n\n#### Nicholas Merizzi\n\nPrincipal | Silicon2Service US leader | Deloitte Consulting LLP\n\nnmerizzi@deloitte.com\n\n+1 214-840-7834\n\n#### Nitin Mittal\n\nGlobal AI leader | Principal | Deloitte Consulting LLP\n\nnmittal@deloitte.com\n\n+1 617 831 4128\n\n#### Tim Smith\n\nPrincipal | US Monitor Deloitte Strategy Offering Leader\n\ntimsmith6@deloitte.com\n\n+1 212 313 2979\n\n#### Gaurav Churiwala\n\nUSI Tech, AI and Data Strategy Leader\n\ngchuriwala@deloitte.com [...] gchuriwala@deloitte.com\n\n+1 615 718 5507\n\n#### Diana Kearns-Manolatos\n\nSenior manager | Subject matter specialist | Deloitte Services LP\n\n+1 212 436 3301\n\n### Insights to guide your AI journey\n\n### As cloud costs rise, hybrid solutions are redefining the path to scaling AI\n\nDeloitte research reveals how rising cloud costs are prompting organizations to blend legacy systems with emerging solutions to scale AI more efficiently\n\n### Is your organization’s infrastructure ready for the new hybrid cloud?\n\nAre costs and modernization needs hindering AI's potential?       "content": "Redefining work: Around 60% of current jobs didn't exist in the 1940s, showcasing the need for reskilling and adaptation to new roles. HR's role is to lead organisations through this change and identify critical future skills for the digital age.\n Transformation challenges: Around 80% of HR tech projects fail to achieve intended ROI or solve business problems. David emphasises that organisations should focus on problem-solving rather than adopting technology for its own sake.\n Strategic intent: David's recommendations for organisations include starting with a people-centric approach, embracing digital transformation as a cultural shift, and taking intentional steps toward technology adoption aligned with the organisation's strategic agenda. [...] Jared Cameron, Principal Digital HR and Technology, Mercer New Zealand, said that in just 12 months, generative AI has become part of everyday work for many organisations and highlighted that the use cases for AI in HR go well beyond efficiency gains from writing job descriptions. As we dial up the complexity of what AI can do, he sees potential for more personalised learning and better insights into employee experience. But to leverage AI companies will need a strong foundation with data on talent skills, careers and job architecture.\n 44:49 - The audience makes their bet\n 50:40 - Questions from the audience\n\n### \n\nResources [...] Insights for HR leaders in this episode\n\n Importance of skills in the future of work and benefits of skills-powered model\n Key challenges and considerations when implementing a skills-powered approach, such as ensuring privacy and data protection, integrating with existing technology and effectively managing change\n Importance of collaboration between the organisation, technology partners and change management\n Conditions for a successful journey, including strong leadership support and stakeholder engagement\n Test and learn phases and the need for flexibility and continuous adaptation\n Effective strategies for driving change and facilitating communication throughout the transformation process\n Practical suggestions for organisations considering a similar transition.",

      "content": "Turnkey integrations with major HRIS and payroll systems—including Workday, UKG, ADP, SAP SuccessFactors, Oracle, BambooHR, and Rippling—enable automated data flows rather than manual uploads each cycle.\n Single sign-on support through common identity providers like Okta and Azure AD ensures seamless access while maintaining security standards.\n The ability to import existing survey data from providers like Mercer, Radford, ERI, and Culpepper protects previous investments while enabling gradual transition to real-time datasets. [...] Discovery Phase\n\nThe discovery phase involves auditing current systems, data quality, and process documentation to identify integration requirements and potential challenges.  HR teams should inventory their existing technology stack—HRIS, payroll, performance management, equity administration, and ATS platforms—along with current data flows and manual processes. Reviewing compensation philosophy documentation, job architecture consistency, and range-setting procedures helps identify areas where platform capabilities can immediately add value versus areas requiring process redesign. [...] Training should be role-specific and workflow-focused: managers need to understand how to access employee data, interpret market positioning, and enter recommendations within budget guidelines, while HR teams require broader platform knowledge for configuration, reporting, and analytical capabilities.       "url": "https://www.mercer.com/insights/talent-and-transformation/skill-based-talent-management/rebuilding-reward-and-career-frameworks-based-on-skills/",
      "title": "The 2025/2026 Skills Snapshot Survey report",
      "content": "91% of companies see AI transforming their workforce and are planning how to respond. They’re using skills strategically to attract talent, connect the right people to the right work and stay ahead of shifting work demands.\n\nThey’re using skills strategically to attract talent, connect the right people to the right work and stay ahead of shifting work demands.\n\n## Key points we address in the research\n\n## Rising maturity in incorporating skills into talent practices\n\nThe 2025/2026 Skills Snapshot Survey reveals continued momentum in embedding skills into talent management practices. Organizations are steadily advancing foundational capabilities that enable a skills-powered workforce.\n\n38% of organizations now maintain a single, enterprise-wide skills library, up from 30% in 2023. [...] As part of the skills-powered journey, employers are progressing with leveraging skills in their talent and rewards strategies. This improves employee retention, enhances workforce agility and allows greater flexibility in responding to evolving market demands.\n\nThe 2025/2026 Skills Snapshot Survey report delves into the strategic importance of building a skills-powered organization, highlighting how this evolving approach unlocks greater workforce agility, drives innovation, and positions businesses for sustainable growth in an increasingly dynamic and technology-enabled market.\n\nAI plays a central role in both shaping and enabling this journey, rapidly reshaping skill requirements and premiums and enabling skills development and deployment. [...] 55% map skills directly to jobs, a significant increase from 47% in 2023.\n\nThe mean percentage of jobs with skills mapped has grown to 72%, up from 69% in 2023.\n\nThese gains demonstrate a rising maturity in skills adoption, laying the groundwork for more effective talent strategies and workforce agility.\n\nCover\n\n## Ready to get started?\n\nSkills Edge Go-to-Market Leader\n\nResearch and Insights Leader\n\nPh.D., Analytics Specialist\n\n## Related topics\n\n## Download the report\n\nMarsh\nFollow on WeChat",
